name: Adhirasam
ingredients: Rice flour, jaggery, ghee, vegetable oil, elachi
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of rice flour and 1/2 cup of jaggery powder, and mix well until the jaggery is evenly distributed.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of elachi powder to the mixture and mix well.
Gradually add 1/4 cup of ghee to the mixture and mix until it forms a smooth dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Heat 2-3 inches of vegetable oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
When the oil is hot, carefully slide in a few dough balls and fry until they are golden brown, about 3-4 minutes.
Remove the fried adhirasam from the oil with a slotted spoon and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Repeat the frying process with the remaining dough balls.
Let the adhirasam cool completely before storing them in an airtight container.

name: Aloo gobi
ingredients: Cauliflower, potato, garam masala, turmeric, curry leaves
instructions:
Peel and dice the potato into small cubes and set aside.
Rinse the cauliflower florets and pat them dry with a paper towel to remove excess moisture.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat and add the curry leaves, letting them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add the diced potato to the pan and sauté until they start to turn light golden brown, about 5 minutes.
Add the cauliflower florets to the pan and stir well to combine with the potatoes and curry leaves.
Sprinkle the turmeric powder over the vegetables and stir well to coat evenly.
Sprinkle the garam masala powder over the vegetables and stir well to combine.
Continue to cook the vegetables for another 10-12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they are tender and lightly browned.
Season with salt to taste, then serve hot.

name: Aloo matar
ingredients: Potato, peas, chillies, ginger, garam masala, garlic
instructions:
Peel and dice the potatoes into small cubes and set aside.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté the diced chillies until they start to soften.
Add the minced ginger and garlic to the pan and sauté for another minute until fragrant.
Add the diced potatoes to the pan and sauté for about 5 minutes until they start to brown.
Add a cup of water to the pan and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let the potatoes cook until they are half-done.
Add the peas to the pan and stir well to combine with the potatoes and spices.
Add the garam masala powder to the pan and stir well to combine.
Continue to cook the mixture for another 5-7 minutes until the potatoes are fully cooked and the peas are tender.
Season with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Aloo methi
ingredients: Potato, fenugreek leaves, chillies, salt, oil
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 2-3 chopped green chillies to the pan and sauté for 1 minute.
Add 2 cups of chopped fenugreek leaves to the pan and sauté until they are wilted and reduced in size.
Peel and dice 2 large potatoes into small cubes and add them to the pan.
Sprinkle 1 teaspoon of salt over the potatoes and mix well.
Mix everything together and sauté for 5-7 minutes or until the potatoes are cooked through and golden brown.
Serve hot.

name: Aloo shimla mirch
ingredients: Potato, shimla mirch, garam masala, amchur powder, salt
instructions:
Peel and dice the potatoes into small cubes and wash them thoroughly.
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add the diced potatoes to it.
Let the potatoes cook for 5-7 minutes or until they are half-cooked, stirring occasionally.
Add 1-2 diced shimla mirch to the pan and sauté for another 2-3 minutes.
Sprinkle 1/2 teaspoon of garam masala powder over the potatoes and shimla mirch and mix well.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of amchur powder and salt to taste to the pan and mix again.
Continue cooking for another 2-3 minutes or until the potatoes are fully cooked and the shimla mirch is tender.
Serve the aloo shimla mirch hot, garnished with additional shimla mirch if desired.

name: Aloo tikki
ingredients: Rice flour, potato, bread crumbs, garam masala, salt
instructions:
Boil the potatoes until they are fully cooked, then let them cool down.
Mash the cooled potatoes in a bowl until they are smooth.
Add salt and garam masala to the mashed potatoes and mix well.
Divide the potato mixture into 6-8 portions, depending on how large you want your tikkis to be.
Shape each portion into a round patty, about 1-2 inches thick.
In a shallow dish, mix together rice flour and bread crumbs.
Coat each potato patty with the rice flour and bread crumb mixture, pressing gently to adhere.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and add a small amount of oil.
When the oil is hot, add the coated potato patties and cook for 3-4 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Serve hot and enjoy!

name: Alu Pitika
ingredients: Potatoes, mustard oil, fish, green chillies
instructions:
Peel and boil 2-3 medium-sized potatoes until they are tender, then mash them in a bowl.
Heat 2 tablespoons of mustard oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1-2 green chillies, chopped, to the pan and sauté until they start to change color.
Add 1-2 pieces of fish, chopped, to the pan and cook until they are browned and cooked through.
Add the mashed potatoes to the pan and stir well to combine with the fish and green chillies.
Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until the mixture is heated through and well combined.
Remove the pan from the heat and serve the Alu Pitika hot.

name: Amti
ingredients: Kala masala, arhar dal, curry leaves, mustard seeds, hot water
instructions:
Rinse the arhar dal and soak it in hot water for at least 30 minutes.
Drain the water and blend the soaked dal into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of oil to it.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds to the pan and let them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 5-6 curry leaves to the pan and sauté them until they turn fragrant.
Add the blended dal paste to the pan and sauté it for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add 1 teaspoon of kala masala powder to the pan and mix it well with the dal paste.
Add 2 cups of hot water to the pan and mix it well with the dal paste.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the dal is cooked.
Serve the amti hot, garnished with additional curry leaves if desired.

name: Anarsa
ingredients: Rice flour, jaggery, khus-khus seeds
instructions:
Roast the rice flour in a pan over medium heat, stirring constantly, until it turns light brown and fragrant.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the roasted rice flour cool completely.
Grind the cooled rice flour into a fine powder using a blender or grinder.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the ground rice flour and powdered jaggery, and mix well until the jaggery is fully incorporated.
Add the khus-khus seeds to the bowl and mix until they are evenly distributed throughout the mixture.
Gradually add a small amount of water to the bowl, mixing continuously, until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for about 5 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions, about the size of a small lemon.
Shape each portion into a ball and then flatten it slightly into a disk shape.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the anarsa disks for about 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Remove the anarsa from the pan and let them cool completely on a wire rack.

name: Ariselu
ingredients: Rice flour, jaggery, ghee
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of rice flour and a pinch of salt.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the rice flour mixture and mix well to form a smooth dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Place 1-2 teaspoons of jaggery in the center of each circle.
Fold the dough over the jaggery to form a half-moon shape and press the edges together to seal.
Heat 1-2 tablespoons of ghee in a non-stick pan over medium heat.
When the ghee is hot, add a few ariselu to the pan (do not overcrowd) and cook for 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown.
Remove the cooked ariselu from the pan and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess ghee.
Repeat the cooking process with the remaining ariselu.
Let the ariselu cool completely before storing them in an airtight container.

name: Attu
ingredients: Whole wheat flour, arhar dal, ginger, kala jeera, green chilli
instructions:
Rinse the arhar dal and soak it in water for at least 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the arhar dal into a coarse paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat 1 tablespoon of water in a pan over medium heat and add the grated ginger; sauté until the ginger is soft and fragrant.
Add the ground arhar dal paste to the pan and cook for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens slightly.
Add 1 teaspoon of kala jeera to the pan and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add 1-2 green chillies, finely chopped, to the pan and sauté for 30 seconds.
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of whole wheat flour and the cooked arhar dal mixture; mix well until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 10-15 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a small ball.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle using a rolling pin or your hands.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the attu for 1-2 minutes on each side, until it is golden brown and crispy.

name: Avial
ingredients: Raw banana, elephant foot yam, long beans, tindora, urad dal
instructions:
Peel the raw banana, elephant foot yam, and tindora, and cut them into small pieces.
Cut the long beans into 1-inch pieces.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté the urad dal until it turns light brown.
Add the cut vegetables to the pan and sauté until they are slightly tender.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let the vegetables cook until they are fully tender.
Mash the cooked vegetables using a potato masher or a spoon to desired consistency.
Season with salt to taste.
Serve the Avial hot with rice or roti.

name: Baingan Fry
ingredients: Beef, coconut, garam masala, curry leaves, green chilies, chili powder
instructions:
Cut 2 medium-sized eggplants into 1-inch cubes and set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and add 1 sprig of curry leaves.
Add 2-3 green chilies, chopped, and sauté for a minute until they start to change color.
Add the eggplant cubes and sauté for 5-6 minutes until they start to brown.
Add 1 teaspoon of chili powder and mix well to coat the eggplant evenly.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of garam masala powder and mix again.
Add 1/4 cup of grated coconut and mix well to combine with the eggplant mixture.
Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes until the coconut is lightly toasted and the eggplant is fully coated.
Season with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Bajri no rotlo
ingredients: Wheat flour, pearl millet flour, hot water
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of wheat flour and 1 cup of pearl millet flour.
Gradually add hot water to the flour mixture and mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 10-15 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 6-7 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick skillet or griddle over medium heat.
Place a rotlo on the skillet and cook for 30-45 seconds or until it starts to bubble.
Flip the rotlo and cook for another 30-45 seconds or until it's golden brown.
Repeat with the remaining dough portions.

name: Balu shahi
ingredients: Maida flour, yogurt, oil, sugar
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of Maida flour and 1/2 cup of yogurt to form a smooth dough, adding a little water if needed.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat 2-3 inches of oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
When the oil is hot, carefully slide in a few of the dough circles, not overcrowding the pan.
Fry the dough circles until they are golden brown, about 2-3 minutes on each side.
Remove the fried dough circles from the oil with a slotted spoon and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
In a separate pan, heat 1 cup of sugar over low heat, stirring constantly, until it dissolves and forms a syrup.
Add 1/2 cup of water to the sugar syrup and stir well.
Bring the sugar syrup to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 5-7 minutes, or until it reaches a thick, sticky consistency.
Dip each fried dough circle into the sugar syrup, coating it evenly on both sides.
Place the coated Balu Shahi on a wire rack or tray to cool and harden.

name: Bandar laddu
ingredients: Besan, jaggery, cardamom powder, ghee, cashews and raisins, jaggery syrup, sugar
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of besan and 1 cup of sugar, and mix well until the sugar is evenly distributed.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of cardamom powder to the besan mixture and mix again.
Heat 1/4 cup of ghee in a pan over medium heat and add 1/2 cup of cashews, frying until they are golden brown.
Remove the fried cashews from the ghee and set them aside on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess ghee.
In the same pan, add 1/2 cup of raisins and fry until they are puffed up and golden brown.
Remove the fried raisins from the ghee and set them aside with the cashews.
In a large pan, combine 1 cup of jaggery and 1/2 cup of water, and heat over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the jaggery dissolves and the mixture reaches a syrupy consistency.
Add the fried cashews and raisins to the jaggery syrup and mix well.
Add the besan mixture to the jaggery syrup and mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it is smooth and pliable.
Divide the dough into small portions and shape each portion into a small ball.
Flatten each ball slightly into a disk shape to form the laddus.
Let the laddus cool and dry completely before storing them in an airtight container.

name: Basundi
ingredients: Sugar, milk, nuts
instructions:
Boil 1 liter of milk in a large, heavy-bottomed pan over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until it reduces to half its original quantity.
Add 1 cup of sugar to the reduced milk and stir until it dissolves completely.
Continue to cook the mixture over low heat, stirring frequently, until it thickens and reaches a creamy consistency.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly.
Stir in 1/2 cup of chopped nuts, such as almonds or pistachios, into the milk mixture.
Pour the Basundi mixture into individual serving cups or a large serving dish.
Refrigerate the Basundi for at least 2 hours or until chilled.
Serve the Basundi chilled, garnished with additional chopped nuts if desired.

name: Bebinca
ingredients: Coconut milk, egg yolks, clarified butter, all purpose flour
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C) and grease a 9x13-inch baking dish with a thin layer of clarified butter.
In a medium bowl, whisk together 1 cup of all-purpose flour and a pinch of salt, then set aside.
In a large bowl, whisk together 1 1/2 cups of coconut milk and 4 large egg yolks until well combined.
Gradually add the flour mixture to the coconut milk mixture, whisking continuously until smooth and free of lumps.
Pour the mixture into the prepared baking dish and bake for 20-25 minutes, or until the edges are set and the center is still slightly jiggly.
Remove the dish from the oven and let it cool slightly, then dot the top with small amounts of clarified butter.
Return the dish to the oven and bake for an additional 5-7 minutes, or until the top is golden brown and the Bebinca is set.
Remove the dish from the oven and let it cool completely before serving.

name: Bengena Pitika
ingredients: Brinjal, onions, salt, sesame seeds, coriander
instructions:
Roast the brinjals over an open flame or in the oven until the skin is charred and the flesh is soft.
Peel the roasted brinjals and mash the flesh in a bowl using a fork or potato masher.
Heat a pan over medium heat and sauté the onions until they are translucent and lightly browned.
Add the mashed brinjal to the pan and stir well to combine with the onions.
Add salt to taste and mix well.
Sprinkle sesame seeds over the brinjal mixture and stir well to combine.
Add coriander powder to the pan and mix well.
Continue cooking the mixture for another 2-3 minutes, stirring frequently, until the flavors are well combined and the pitika is heated through.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the Bengena Pitika cool to room temperature before serving.

name: Bhakri
ingredients: Jowar flour, sesame seeds
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of jowar flour and 1 tablespoon of sesame seeds.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the bowl and mix until a soft dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 6-7 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and place a bhakri on it.
Cook the bhakri for 30-45 seconds on the first side, until it starts to puff up and the edges start to curl.
Flip the bhakri and cook for another 30-45 seconds, until it is golden brown and crispy.
Repeat the process with the remaining dough portions and serve the bhakris hot.

name: Bhatura
ingredients: Chole, rava, yogurt, plain flour, baking soda
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of plain flour, 1 teaspoon of baking soda, and 1/4 teaspoon of salt.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of yogurt to the flour mixture and mix until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 2 hours in a warm place.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 6-7 inches in diameter.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium-high heat and when hot, slide in a rolled-out dough circle.
Fry the Bhatura until it puffs up and the edges start to curl, about 2-3 minutes.
Flip the Bhatura over and fry for another 1-2 minutes, until it's golden brown.
Remove the Bhatura from the oil and place it on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve the Bhatura hot with a bowl of Chole and sprinkle some Rava on top, if desired.

name: Bhindi masala
ingredients: Ladies finger, garam masala, kasuri methi, tomatoes, chili powder
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds and let them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 250 grams of ladies finger, cut into 1-inch pieces, and sauté until they start to change color.
Add 1 teaspoon of chili powder and sauté for another minute.
Add 2 medium-sized tomatoes, diced, and sauté until they are soft and mushy.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder and 1/2 teaspoon of kasuri methi, and sauté for 30 seconds.
Add 1/2 cup of water, salt to taste, and mix well.
Cover the pan with a lid and let it simmer for 10-12 minutes or until the ladies finger is cooked through.
Serve hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Bilahi Maas
ingredients: Potatoes, garam masala, tomatoes, mustard oil, bay leaf
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of mustard oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1 bay leaf to the pan and let it sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 2-3 diced potatoes to the pan and sauté until they are golden brown.
Add 1 diced tomato to the pan and sauté for another 2-3 minutes.
Sprinkle 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder over the potatoes and tomatoes and mix well.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let the mixture simmer for 10-12 minutes or until the potatoes are cooked through.
Serve the Bilahi Maas hot, garnished with additional garam masala powder if desired.

name: Biryani
ingredients: Chicken thighs, basmati rice, star anise, sweet, green chillies
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat and add 2 whole star anise to sizzle for 10 seconds.
Add 1 pound boneless, skinless chicken thighs to the pan and cook until browned, about 5-6 minutes, then set aside.
In the same pan, add 1 large onion, diced, and cook until translucent, about 3-4 minutes.
Add 2-3 green chillies, chopped, to the pan and cook for an additional minute.
Add 1 cup of basmati rice to the pan and stir to coat the rice with oil and mix with the onion and chilli mixture for 2 minutes.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the rice is cooked and fluffy.
Add the cooked chicken back to the pan, stirring gently to combine with the rice and cook for an additional 2-3 minutes.
Turn off the heat and let the biryani rest, covered, for 5 minutes before serving.

name: Bisi bele bath
ingredients: Split pigeon peas, chana dal, urad dal, green peas, french beans
instructions:
Rinse the split pigeon peas, chana dal, and urad dal together and soak them in water for at least 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the soaked dal mixture into a coarse paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pressure cooker over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them splutter for a few seconds.
Add 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds and let them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 1 small onion, finely chopped, and sauté until it turns translucent.
Add 2 cloves of garlic, minced, and sauté for another minute.
Add 1 cup of green peas and 1 cup of french beans, chopped, and sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Add 2 cups of water to the pressure cooker and bring to a boil.
Add the ground dal paste, 1 teaspoon of turmeric powder, and 1 teaspoon of salt to the pressure cooker.
Close the lid of the pressure cooker and cook for 3-4 whistles or until the dal is cooked and mushy.
Let the pressure release naturally, then open the lid and mash the dal mixture using a potato masher or a spoon.
Add 2 tablespoons of ghee to the dal mixture and mix well.
Serve the bisi bele bath hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Black rice
ingredients: Forbidden black rice, chicken, olive oil, slivered almonds, garlic powder
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of Forbidden black rice in a fine-mesh strainer under cold running water, then drain and set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a medium saucepan over medium-high heat.
Add 1 cup of diced chicken to the saucepan and cook until browned, about 5-7 minutes, then remove from heat and set aside.
In the same saucepan, add 1 teaspoon of garlic powder and cook for 1 minute, stirring constantly.
Add the rinsed black rice to the saucepan and cook for 1-2 minutes, stirring constantly, until the rice is coated in the garlic oil mixture.
Add 2 cups of water to the saucepan and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low, cover the saucepan with a tight-fitting lid, and simmer for 20-25 minutes or until the water is absorbed and the rice is tender.
Once the rice is cooked, fluff it with a fork and stir in the cooked chicken and 1/4 cup of slivered almonds.
Serve hot.

name: Bombil fry
ingredients: Bombay duck, malvani masala, rice flour, bombay rava, green chilies
instructions:
Clean and wash the Bombay duck pieces, pat them dry with a paper towel to remove excess moisture.
In a bowl, mix together 1/2 cup of rice flour, 1/4 cup of bombay rava, and 1 teaspoon of malvani masala powder.
Add the mixed dry ingredients to the Bombay duck pieces and coat them evenly, shaking off any excess.
Heat 1/2 inch of oil in a deep frying pan over medium-high heat until it reaches 350°F.
Once the oil is hot, add 2-3 coated Bombay duck pieces to the oil, being careful not to overcrowd the pan.
Fry the Bombay duck pieces for 3-4 minutes on each side, or until they are golden brown and crispy.
Remove the fried Bombay duck pieces from the oil with a slotted spoon and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Repeat the frying process with the remaining coated Bombay duck pieces.
In the same oil, add 1-2 slit green chilies and fry for 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until they are crispy.
Remove the fried green chilies from the oil and place them on top of the fried Bombay duck pieces.
Serve the Bombil fry hot with the fried green chilies on top.

name: Boondi
ingredients: Gram flour, ghee, sugar
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of gram flour and a pinch of salt.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the bowl and mix until a smooth batter forms.
Add 1 tablespoon of ghee to the batter and mix well.
Cover the bowl with a cloth and let the batter rest for 30 minutes.
Heat enough ghee in a deep frying pan over medium heat to deep-fry the boondi.
Using a spoon, drop small droplets of the batter into the hot ghee, about the size of a small pea.
Fry the boondi until they are golden brown, stirring occasionally, for about 5-7 minutes.
Remove the fried boondi from the ghee with a slotted spoon and drain excess ghee on paper towels.
In a separate pan, heat 1 cup of sugar over low heat, stirring constantly, until the sugar dissolves and forms a syrup.
Add the fried boondi to the sugar syrup and stir well to coat the boondi evenly.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the boondi cool completely before serving.

name: Bora Sawul
ingredients: Biryani masala, mixed vegetables, yellow moong daal, whole red, mustard seeds
instructions:
Rinse the yellow moong daal and soak it in water for at least 30 minutes, then drain and set aside.
Heat oil in a large pan over medium heat and add whole red mustard seeds, letting them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add the mixed vegetables to the pan and sauté until they are tender and lightly browned.
Add the drained moong daal to the pan and stir to combine with the vegetables and mustard seeds.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the daal is cooked.
Stir in 1 teaspoon of Biryani masala into the pan and let it simmer for another 5 minutes.
Serve the Bora Sawul hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Brown Rice
ingredients: Brown rice, soy sauce, olive oil
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of brown rice in a fine mesh strainer under cold running water until the water runs clear.
In a medium saucepan, heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil over medium heat.
Add the rinsed brown rice to the saucepan and stir to coat the rice with the olive oil.
Cook the rice for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until the rice is lightly toasted and fragrant.
Add 2 cups of water to the saucepan and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low, cover the saucepan with a tight-fitting lid, and simmer for 40-45 minutes, or until the water is absorbed and the rice is tender.
Remove the saucepan from the heat and stir in 1 teaspoon of soy sauce.
Let the rice sit, covered, for 5 minutes before serving.

name: Butter chicken
ingredients: Chicken, greek yogurt, cream, garam masala powder, cashew nuts, butter
instructions:
In a large bowl, mix together 1/2 cup of Greek yogurt, 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder, and 1/2 teaspoon of salt, then add 1 pound of boneless, skinless chicken breast or thighs and marinate for at least 30 minutes.
Heat 2 tablespoons of butter in a large skillet over medium heat, then add the marinated chicken and cook until browned on all sides and cooked through, about 6-8 minutes.
Remove the cooked chicken from the skillet and set aside, leaving the remaining butter in the skillet.
Add 1/4 cup of cashew nuts to the skillet and cook, stirring frequently, until they are lightly browned and fragrant, about 2-3 minutes.
Add 1 cup of heavy cream to the skillet and stir to combine with the cashew nuts and remaining butter, bringing the mixture to a simmer.
Reduce the heat to low and let the cream sauce simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it thickens slightly and coats the back of a spoon.
Add the cooked chicken back to the skillet and stir to coat with the cream sauce, then cook for an additional 1-2 minutes until the chicken is fully coated.
Serve the butter chicken hot, garnished with additional cashew nuts and a sprinkle of garam masala powder if desired.

name: Chak Hao Kheer
ingredients: Rice, milk, sugar, cardamom
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the rice into a fine paste using a blender or grinder.
In a large, heavy-bottomed pan, combine 3 cups of milk, 1 cup of sugar, and 1/2 teaspoon of ground cardamom.
Bring the milk mixture to a boil over high heat, stirring occasionally.
Reduce the heat to low and add the rice paste to the milk mixture, stirring constantly to prevent lumps.
Cook for 10-12 minutes, stirring frequently, until the kheer thickens and the rice is fully cooked.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the kheer cool to room temperature.
Refrigerate the kheer for at least 2 hours or overnight to allow the flavors to meld together.
Serve the Chak Hao Kheer chilled, garnished with a sprinkle of cardamom powder if desired.

name: Chakali
ingredients: Rice flour, sesame, plain flour, turmeric, red chilli
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of rice flour and 1 cup of plain flour.
Add 1 teaspoon of turmeric powder and mix well.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the flour mixture and mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Sprinkle a few sesame seeds in the center of each circle.
Fold the dough over the sesame seeds to form a triangle or a square shape, and press the edges to seal.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat, and when hot, add a few of the dough shapes to the oil.
Fry the Chakali until they are golden brown, turning them occasionally, for about 3-4 minutes.
Remove the fried Chakali from the oil and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Sprinkle a pinch of red chilli powder over the fried Chakali while they are still warm.
Serve the Chakali warm or at room temperature.

name: Cham cham
ingredients: Flour, cream, sugar, saffron, lemon juice, coconut flakes
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of flour and 1/2 cup of sugar.
Gradually add in 1/2 cup of cream and mix until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small egg.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 1/8 inch thick.
In a small bowl, mix together 1/4 teaspoon of saffron threads with 1 tablespoon of lemon juice.
Place a small spoonful of the saffron mixture in the center of each dough circle.
Fold the dough over the filling to form a triangle or a square shape, and press the edges to seal.
Heat a large skillet or frying pan over medium heat and cook the cham cham for 2-3 minutes on each side, until golden brown.
Sprinkle coconut flakes over the cooked cham cham and serve warm.

name: Chana masala
ingredients: Chickpeas, tomato paste, garam masala, ginger, red onion, avocado oil
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of avocado oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger and sauté for 1 minute until fragrant.
Add 1 medium diced red onion and sauté for 5 minutes until softened and lightly browned.
Add 2 tablespoons of tomato paste and sauté for 1 minute, stirring constantly.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala and sauté for 30 seconds, stirring constantly.
Add 1 can of chickpeas (drained and rinsed) and stir to combine with the spice mixture.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring to a simmer.
Reduce heat to low and let the mixture cook for 20-25 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sauce has thickened and the chickpeas are coated.
Season with salt to taste, then serve hot.

name: Chapati
ingredients: Whole wheat flour, olive oil, hot water, all purpose flour
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of whole wheat flour and 1/2 cup of all-purpose flour.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of hot water to the flour mixture and mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 6-7 inches in diameter.
Brush the surface of each chapati with a little olive oil.
Heat a non-stick skillet or griddle over medium heat and cook the chapati for 30-45 seconds on each side, until it puffs up and has brown spots.
Serve the chapati hot with your favorite filling or topping.

name: Cheera Doi
ingredients: Rice, mango, curd
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the soaked rice into a fine paste using a blender or grinder.
In a large bowl, mix 1 cup of curd with the rice paste until smooth and well combined.
Peel and dice 1 ripe mango into small pieces and add it to the curd-rice mixture.
Mix everything well until the mango is evenly distributed throughout the mixture.
Cover the bowl with a lid and refrigerate it for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve the Cheera Doi chilled, garnished with a sprinkle of cardamom powder or chopped nuts if desired.

name: Chevdo
ingredients: Citric acid, fry, raisins, sugar, chana daal
instructions:
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat and fry the chana daal until it turns light golden brown and crispy.
Remove the fried chana daal from the oil and place it on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the fried chana daal, sugar, and citric acid, and mix well until the sugar is evenly distributed.
Add the raisins to the bowl and mix until they are evenly distributed among the chana daal mixture.
Let the mixture cool completely to room temperature.
Once cooled, mix the ingredients again to redistribute the raisins and sugar evenly.
Store the chevdo in an airtight container for up to a week.

name: Chhena jalebi
ingredients: Chhena, sugar, ghee
instructions:
Heat 1 tablespoon of ghee in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
Once the ghee is hot, add a small portion of chhena to the pan and flatten it slightly to form a round shape.
Fry the chhena until it is golden brown, flipping it occasionally, for about 3-4 minutes.
Remove the fried chhena from the pan and place it on a paper towel to drain excess ghee.
In a separate pan, combine 1 cup of sugar and 1 cup of water and bring to a boil over high heat.
Reduce the heat to medium and simmer the sugar syrup for about 5-7 minutes, or until it reaches a thick, syrupy consistency.
Add the fried chhena to the sugar syrup and coat it evenly.
Remove the jalebi from the syrup and place it on a serving plate.
Repeat the process with the remaining chhena and serve the chhena jalebis warm or at room temperature.

name: Chhena kheeri
ingredients: Chhena, sugar, milk
instructions:
Boil 1 liter of milk in a large vessel over medium heat until it reduces to half its original quantity.
Add 1/2 cup of sugar to the reduced milk and stir until the sugar is completely dissolved.
Remove the vessel from the heat and let the sweetened milk cool down to room temperature.
Crumble 250 gm of chhena into the cooled milk and mix well until the chhena is fully incorporated and the mixture is smooth.
Refrigerate the mixture for at least 2 hours or overnight to allow it to chill and set.
Once set, scoop the chhena kheeri into individual serving bowls and serve chilled.

name: Chhena poda
ingredients: Sugar, chenna cheese
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C).
In a mixing bowl, crumble 250 grams of chenna cheese into small pieces.
Add 1 cup of sugar to the crumbled chenna cheese and mix well until the sugar is evenly distributed.
Transfer the mixture to a greased baking dish and press it down firmly to remove any air pockets.
Bake the mixture in the preheated oven for 30-40 minutes or until the edges start to turn golden brown.
Remove the dish from the oven and let it cool for 10-15 minutes.
Use a spatula to scrape the top layer of the chhena poda, which will be slightly caramelized and crispy.
Cut the chhena poda into desired shapes and sizes, and serve warm or at room temperature.

name: Chicken razala
ingredients: Chicken, dahi, sesame seeds, garam masala powder, cashew nuts, saffron
instructions:
Marinate the chicken in a mixture of dahi, garam masala powder, and a pinch of saffron for at least 30 minutes.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté the cashew nuts until they are lightly browned.
Add the marinated chicken to the pan and cook until it is browned on all sides and cooked through.
Remove the chicken from the pan and set it aside on a plate.
In the same pan, add 1 tablespoon of oil and sauté the sesame seeds until they are lightly browned.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring it to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and add the cooked chicken back to the pan.
Simmer the chicken in the sauce for 5-7 minutes or until the sauce has thickened and the chicken is fully coated.
Serve the Chicken Razala hot, garnished with additional sesame seeds and a sprinkle of saffron if desired.

name: Chicken Tikka
ingredients: Chicken, whole wheat bread, rice flour, garam masala powder, whole egg
instructions:
Cut the chicken into small cubes and place them in a bowl.
In a separate bowl, whisk together 1 whole egg, 1 teaspoon garam masala powder, and a pinch of salt until well combined.
Add the egg mixture to the chicken cubes and mix well to coat the chicken evenly.
Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes or up to 2 hours to marinate.
Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C).
Remove the chicken from the refrigerator and thread the marinated chicken cubes onto metal skewers, if using.
Place the skewers on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, leaving a little space between each skewer to allow for even cooking.
Bake the chicken in the preheated oven for 12-15 minutes, or until it is cooked through and slightly charred.
Meanwhile, toast the whole wheat bread until it is lightly browned and crispy.
Grind the toasted bread into fine crumbs using a blender or food processor.
In a shallow dish, mix together the rice flour and bread crumbs.
Remove the baked chicken from the oven and roll each piece in the rice flour mixture to coat evenly.
Serve the Chicken Tikka hot, garnished with fresh cilantro or scallions, if desired.

name: Chicken Tikka masala
ingredients: Naan bread, tomato sauce, skinless chicken breasts, heavy cream, garam masala
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C).
Cut the skinless chicken breasts into 1-inch (2.5 cm) cubes and place them in a bowl.
Sprinkle 1 teaspoon of garam masala over the chicken cubes and mix well to coat.
Place the chicken cubes on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper and bake for 15-20 minutes, or until cooked through.
While the chicken is baking, heat the tomato sauce in a large saucepan over medium heat.
Once the chicken is cooked, remove it from the oven and add it to the saucepan with the tomato sauce.
Stir in 1/2 cup of heavy cream and bring the mixture to a simmer.
Reduce the heat to low and let the sauce simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it thickens slightly.
Warm the Naan bread by wrapping it in foil and heating it in the oven for 2-3 minutes.
Serve the chicken tikka masala over the warmed Naan bread.

name: Chicken Varuval
ingredients: Meat curry powder, chicken chunks, ginger, tomato, cinnamon
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger and sauté until fragrant for about 1 minute.
Add 1 large diced tomato and sauté until it starts to break down for about 3-4 minutes.
Add 1 teaspoon of Meat curry powder and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add 1 cinnamon stick and sauté for 30 seconds.
Add 1 pound of chicken chunks and sauté until they are coated with the spice mixture and start to brown for about 5 minutes.
Add 1/2 cup of water, stir well, and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low, cover the pan, and simmer for 20-25 minutes or until the chicken is cooked through.
Remove the cinnamon stick and serve hot.

name: Chikki
ingredients: Peanuts, jaggery
instructions:
Roast the peanuts in a pan over medium heat, stirring frequently, until they turn light brown and fragrant.
Remove the peanuts from the pan and set them aside to cool.
In the same pan, add 1-2 cups of water and place it over medium heat, stirring until the water starts to boil.
Add the jaggery to the boiling water and stir until it dissolves completely, creating a syrup-like consistency.
Bring the jaggery syrup to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for about 10-15 minutes, or until it reaches a thick, sticky consistency.
Add the roasted peanuts to the jaggery syrup and stir until they are evenly coated.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly, until the mixture is still warm but not hot.
Grease a flat surface, such as a granite or marble countertop, with a small amount of ghee or oil.
Pour the peanut-jaggery mixture onto the greased surface and spread it evenly to form a thin layer.
Allow the mixture to cool and set completely, which may take about 30-40 minutes, depending on the temperature and humidity.
Once set, use a sharp knife or cookie cutter to cut the chikki into desired shapes and sizes.
Serve the chikki immediately, or store it in an airtight container for up to a week.

name: Chingri Bhape
ingredients: Coconut, prawns, curd, mustard seed, green chili
instructions:
Grind 1/2 cup of grated coconut into a fine paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds until they start to splutter.
Add 1-2 green chilies, chopped, to the pan and sauté for another minute.
Add 1 cup of prawns, cleaned and deveined, to the pan and sauté until they turn pink and are half-cooked.
In a separate bowl, mix 1/2 cup of curd with 1 tablespoon of water and 1 teaspoon of salt.
Add the curd mixture to the pan and stir well to combine with the prawns and spices.
Add the coconut paste to the pan and stir well to combine with the prawn mixture.
Reduce heat to low and simmer the mixture for 5-7 minutes or until the prawns are fully cooked and the sauce has thickened.
Serve the Chingri Bhape hot with steamed rice.

name: Chingri malai curry
ingredients: Coconut milk, lobster, fresh green chilli, ginger, red onion
instructions:
Peel and dice the red onion into small pieces and set aside.
Grate the ginger into a fine paste and set aside.
Cut the fresh green chilli into small pieces and set aside.
Cut the lobster into small pieces, wash and pat dry with a paper towel.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a deep pan over medium heat.
Add the diced red onion and sauté until it turns light golden brown.
Add the grated ginger and sauté for another minute until fragrant.
Add the cut green chilli and sauté for 30 seconds until it starts to soften.
Add the lobster pieces and sauté for 2-3 minutes until they start to change color.
Pour in 1 cup of coconut milk and stir well to combine.
Bring the mixture to a simmer and let cook for 5-7 minutes until the lobster is cooked through and the sauce thickens.
Season with salt to taste and remove from heat.
Serve the Chingri malai curry hot, garnished with additional green chilli if desired.

name: Chole bhature
ingredients: Chole, bhatura, garam masala, bay leaf, cinnamon stick
instructions:
Heat oil in a deep pan over medium heat and add a bay leaf and a cinnamon stick to it.
Let the bay leaf and cinnamon stick sizzle for a few seconds until fragrant.
Add the chole to the pan and stir well to combine with the oil and spices.
Add a pinch of garam masala to the chole and stir well to combine.
Let the chole simmer for 10-15 minutes over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the flavors have melded together and the chole has thickened slightly.
Meanwhile, heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
When the oil is hot, add a bhatura to the pan and fry until it puffs up and is golden brown in color.
Flip the bhatura over and fry for another minute until the other side is also golden brown.
Remove the bhatura from the oil and place it on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve the hot bhatura with the simmering chole.

name: Chorafali
ingredients: Urad dal, bengal gram flour, dried mango, baking soda, black salt
instructions:
Rinse the urad dal and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the urad dal into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the ground urad dal paste, bengal gram flour, and baking soda; mix well.
Add black salt to the mixture and mix until it's evenly distributed.
Cover the mixture and let it ferment in a warm place for 24 hours or until it becomes frothy and doubled in volume.
Once fermented, add dried mango powder to the mixture and mix well.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
Using a spoon, drop small portions of the fermented mixture into the hot oil, about the size of a small marble.
Fry the chorafali until they are golden brown and crispy, about 3-4 minutes on each side.
Remove the fried chorafali from the oil with a slotted spoon and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve the chorafali warm or at room temperature.

name: Churma Ladoo
ingredients: Whole wheat flour, khus khus, sesame seeds, dry coconut, gur
instructions:
Roast 1 cup of whole wheat flour in a pan over medium heat, stirring constantly, until it turns light brown and fragrant.
Remove the roasted flour from the pan and set it aside to cool.
In the same pan, roast 1/2 cup of khus khus over medium heat, stirring constantly, until it turns light brown and fragrant.
Remove the roasted khus khus from the pan and set it aside to cool.
In the same pan, roast 1/2 cup of sesame seeds over medium heat, stirring constantly, until they turn light brown and fragrant.
Remove the roasted sesame seeds from the pan and set them aside to cool.
Grate 1/2 cup of dry coconut and set it aside.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the cooled roasted flour, khus khus, sesame seeds, and grated dry coconut.
Add 1/2 cup of crumbled gur to the bowl and mix until well combined.
Gradually add 1/4 cup of ghee to the bowl and mix until the mixture comes together to form a dough.
Divide the dough into small portions and shape each portion into a round ladoo.
Serve the Churma Ladoo warm or store them in an airtight container for up to 5 days.

name: Coconut vadi
ingredients: Condensed milk, mawa, desiccated coconut, almonds, cashews
instructions:
In a large pan, combine 1 can of condensed milk and 1 cup of mawa, and place it over medium heat, stirring constantly.
Continue cooking the mixture for about 10-12 minutes, or until it thickens and turns a light brown color, stirring frequently.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly, until the mixture reaches a temperature that is comfortable to handle.
Add 1 cup of desiccated coconut to the mixture and mix well until the coconut is fully incorporated.
Knead the mixture for about 5-7 minutes, until it forms a smooth and pliable dough.
Divide the dough into small portions, about the size of a small lemon.
Shape each portion into a cylindrical shape, about 2-3 inches long and 1 inch in diameter.
Roll each vadi in desiccated coconut to coat, pressing the coconut gently onto the vadi to ensure it sticks.
Place a few chopped almonds and cashews on top of each vadi, pressing them gently onto the surface.
Let the vadi cool and set at room temperature for at least 30 minutes before serving.

name: Copra paak
ingredients: Condensed milk, nestle cream, coconut ice, red food coloring, desiccated coconut
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 can of condensed milk and 1 cup of Nestle cream, whisking until smooth and well combined.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of red food coloring to the mixture and whisk until the color is evenly distributed.
In a separate bowl, grate 1 cup of coconut ice using a fine grater or food processor until it resembles fine crumbs.
Add the grated coconut ice to the condensed milk mixture and whisk until well combined.
Stir in 1 cup of desiccated coconut into the mixture until it is evenly distributed.
Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate the mixture for at least 2 hours or overnight to allow it to set.
Once set, scoop the mixture into small balls, about 1 inch in diameter, and refrigerate for another 30 minutes to firm up.
Serve the Copra Paak chilled, garnished with additional desiccated coconut if desired.

name: Currivepillai sadam
ingredients: Chana dal, urad dal, fresh coconut, sesame seeds, curry leaves
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of chana dal and 1/2 cup of urad dal together and soak them in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the dal mixture into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of sesame seeds and let them splutter.
Add 5-6 curry leaves to the pan and sauté until they turn light brown and fragrant.
Add 1 cup of fresh coconut gratings to the pan and sauté until they turn light brown and fragrant.
Add the ground dal paste to the pan and sauté for about 5 minutes, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens and turns light brown.
Remove the pan from heat and let the mixture cool down completely.
Once cooled, mix the mixture well and shape into small balls, about the size of small lemons.
Flatten each ball slightly into a disk shape to form the Currivepillai sadam.
Serve the Currivepillai sadam warm or at room temperature.

name: Daal baati churma
ingredients: Moong dal, masoor dal, chana dal, wheat flour, almond
instructions:
Rinse the moong dal, masoor dal, and chana dal together and soak them in water for at least 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the dal mixture into a coarse paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat 2 tablespoons of ghee in a large pan over medium heat and add the ground dal paste.
Cook the dal mixture for 10-12 minutes, stirring frequently, until it thickens and turns light brown.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the daal is cooked and mushy.
Meanwhile, combine 2 cups of wheat flour, 1 teaspoon of salt, and 1/4 teaspoon of baking powder in a large mixing bowl.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the flour mixture and knead it into a soft dough.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Flatten each ball into a disk shape using a rolling pin or your hands.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the baatis for 1-2 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and puffed up.
To make the churma, blend 1/2 cup of almonds into a fine powder using a blender or grinder.
Heat 1 tablespoon of ghee in a pan over low heat and add the almond powder, stirring constantly, until it turns light brown and fragrant.
Add 1/2 cup of sugar to the pan and stir until it dissolves and the mixture turns into a smooth paste.
Serve the daal over the baati, topped with a spoonful of churma and a dollop of ghee, if desired.

name: Daal Dhokli
ingredients: Whole wheat flour, dal, kokum, gur, bengal gram flour
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of whole wheat flour and 1/2 cup of bengal gram flour, mixing well to incorporate.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the flour mixture, kneading to form a smooth dough.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions, shaping each into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
In a large pot, combine 1 cup of dal and 4 cups of water, bringing to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let the dal simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until it is cooked and mushy.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of kokum powder and 1 tablespoon of gur to the cooked dal, stirring well to combine.
Place a rolled-out dough circle into the pot with the dal, pressing it gently into the liquid.
Cook the dhokli for 5-7 minutes, or until it is cooked through and has absorbed the flavors of the dal.
Repeat the process with the remaining dough circles, cooking them one by one in the dal.
Serve the daal dhokli hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Daal puri
ingredients: Moong dal, garam masala powder, garlic, green chilli, all purpose flour
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of moong dal and soak it in water for 30 minutes, then drain the water and set it aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pressure cooker over medium heat and sauté 2-3 minced garlic cloves until fragrant.
Add 1-2 minced green chillies to the pressure cooker and sauté for another minute.
Add the soaked and drained moong dal to the pressure cooker and sauté for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add 2 cups of water and 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder to the pressure cooker, close the lid, and cook for 3-4 whistles or until the dal is cooked and mushy.
Let the pressure cooker cool down, then mash the dal mixture with a spoon or potato masher to desired consistency.
In a separate mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of all-purpose flour and a pinch of salt, then gradually add lukewarm water to form a smooth dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable, then cover it with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Place a tablespoon or two of the cooked dal mixture in the center of each circle, then fold the dough over the filling to form a half-moon shape and press the edges together to seal.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the puris for 30-45 seconds on each side, until they are golden brown and puffed up.
Serve the daal puris hot with a dollop of ghee or butter, if desired.

name: Dahi vada
ingredients: Urad dal, bhuna chana, garam masala, dates, tamarind
instructions:
Rinse the urad dal and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight, then drain and grind it into a smooth paste.
Add bhuna chana to the urad dal paste and mix well.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat and using a spoon, drop small portions of the dal mixture into the oil to form vadas.
Fry the vadas until they are golden brown and crispy, then remove them from the oil and drain on paper towels.
In a large bowl, whisk together 1 cup of yogurt, 1/2 teaspoon of garam masala, and 1/4 teaspoon of salt until smooth.
Soak the fried vadas in the yogurt mixture for at least 30 minutes to allow them to absorb the flavors.
Meanwhile, blend 2 dates and 1 tablespoon of tamarind paste with 1/2 cup of water until smooth to make a sweet and tangy chutney.
To assemble the dahi vada, place a soaked vada on a serving plate, top it with a dollop of the yogurt mixture, and drizzle with the date-tamarind chutney.
Repeat the assembly process with the remaining vadas and serve chilled.

name: Dal makhani
ingredients: Red kidney beans, urad dal, cream, garam masala, chili powder
instructions:
Rinse the red kidney beans and urad dal together and soak them in water for at least 8 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and add 4 cups of fresh water to the soaked dal and beans, then pressure cook them until they are tender and mushy.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté for 1 minute.
Add 1 teaspoon of chili powder to the pan and sauté for another minute, until fragrant.
Add the cooked dal and beans to the pan, stirring well to combine with the chili powder mixture.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder to the pan and stir well to combine.
Reduce heat to low and let the dal simmer for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the flavors have melded together and the dal has thickened slightly.
Stir in 2 tablespoons of cream and continue to simmer for another 5 minutes, until the cream has fully incorporated and the dal has reached the desired consistency.
Serve the dal makhani hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Dal tadka
ingredients: Pigeon peas, garam masala, ginger, red onion, kasuri methi
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of pigeon peas and soak them in water for at least 30 minutes, then drain and set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pressure cooker over medium heat.
Add 1 small finely chopped red onion and sauté until it turns light brown.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger and sauté for another minute.
Add the soaked and drained pigeon peas, 2 cups of water, and 1 teaspoon of garam masala to the pressure cooker.
Close the lid and cook for 3-4 whistles or until the peas are tender.
Let the pressure release naturally, then open the lid and mash some of the peas with a spoon to desired consistency.
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a small pan over medium heat.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of kasuri methi and let it sizzle for a few seconds.
Pour the kasuri methi oil mixture over the cooked dal and mix well.
Serve hot.

name: Dalithoy
ingredients: Arhar dal, coconut oil, curry leaves, mustard seeds, red chilli
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of coconut oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them sizzle for a few seconds until they start to pop.
Add 2-3 curry leaves to the pan and sauté for a few seconds until fragrant.
Add 1-2 dried red chillies, broken into pieces, to the pan and sauté for another few seconds.
Add 1 cup of Arhar dal, rinsed and drained, to the pan and sauté for about 5 minutes, stirring frequently, until the dal is lightly roasted.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low, cover the pan, and let the dal simmer for about 20-25 minutes, or until it is cooked through and mushy.
Season with salt to taste, then serve hot.

name: Dharwad pedha
ingredients: Milk, Sugar, Dharwadi buffalo milk
instructions:
Boil 1 liter of Dharwadi buffalo milk in a large, heavy-bottomed pan over medium heat, stirring occasionally.
Reduce the heat to low and add 1/2 cup of sugar to the boiling milk, stirring constantly to prevent scorching.
Continue cooking the milk mixture for 10-12 minutes, or until it thickens and reduces to half its original volume, stirring frequently.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly, until the mixture reaches 80°C to 90°C (176°F to 194°F).
Add 1/2 cup of whole milk to the mixture and stir well to combine.
Return the pan to low heat and cook for an additional 5-7 minutes, or until the mixture thickens further and reaches a consistency similar to soft dough.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the mixture cool completely to room temperature.
Once cooled, knead the mixture until it becomes smooth and pliable, similar to dough.
Shape the mixture into small, round balls, about 1 inch (2.5 cm) in diameter.
Serve the Dharwad pedha at room temperature, or store them in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.

name: Dhokla
ingredients: Rava, coconut, gram flour, mustard, sesame
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of rava and 1/2 cup of gram flour.
Add 1/2 cup of grated coconut to the bowl and mix well.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of mustard seeds to the bowl and mix again.
Gradually add 1 cup of lukewarm water to the bowl and mix until a smooth batter forms.
Cover the bowl with a cloth and let the batter rest for 30 minutes.
After 30 minutes, add 1 tablespoon of sesame seeds to the batter and mix well.
Grease a dhokla plate or a non-stick pan with a little oil and pour the batter into it.
Steam the dhokla for 15-20 minutes or until it is cooked through and fluffy.
Remove the dhokla from the steamer and let it cool for a few minutes.
Cut the dhokla into squares and serve hot with your favorite chutney or sauce.

name: Dhondas
ingredients: Cucumber, rava
instructions:
Grate the cucumber and squeeze out the excess water using a muslin cloth or a paper towel.
In a bowl, mix together the grated cucumber and rava until well combined.
Add a pinch of salt to the mixture and mix well.
Cover the bowl with a cloth and let the mixture rest for 30 minutes to allow the rava to absorb the moisture.
After 30 minutes, mix the mixture again and check if it has reached a thick but pliable consistency, if not let it rest for another 15 minutes.
Once the mixture is ready, shape it into small cylindrical shapes, about 1 inch in diameter and 2-3 inches long.
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add a few drops of oil to it.
When the oil is hot, add the dhondas to the pan and cook for about 3-4 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and cooked through.
Remove the dhondas from the pan and drain on paper towels.
Serve the dhondas hot with a dollop of butter or a sprinkle of chaat masala, if desired.

name: Doodhpak
ingredients: Milk, rice, sugar, dry fruits
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Drain the water and blend the rice into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
In a large pan, combine 1 liter of milk, 1 cup of sugar, and the rice paste, and whisk until the sugar is dissolved.
Cook the mixture over medium heat, stirring constantly, until it comes to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and simmer for 15-20 minutes, or until the mixture thickens and the rice is fully cooked.
Add 1/2 cup of chopped dry fruits (such as almonds, cashews, and pistachios) to the mixture and stir well.
Continue to simmer for another 5 minutes, or until the dry fruits are fully incorporated and the mixture has thickened to your liking.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the Doodhpak cool to room temperature.
Refrigerate the Doodhpak for at least 2 hours, or until chilled, before serving.

name: Dosa
ingredients: Chana dal, urad dal, whole urad dal, blend rice, rock salt
instructions:
Rinse the chana dal, urad dal, and whole urad dal together and soak them in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the soaked dal mixture into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
Add 2 cups of blend rice to the grinder and grind until the mixture is well combined and the rice is fully broken down.
Transfer the mixture to a large bowl and add rock salt to taste, mixing well.
Cover the bowl with a cloth and let the mixture ferment in a warm place for 12-14 hours or overnight.
After fermentation, the mixture should have risen and have a sour smell; mix it well to redistribute the ingredients.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and grease it with a few drops of water.
Using a ladle, pour a small amount of the fermented mixture onto the pan and spread it evenly to form a circular shape.
Cook the dosa for 1-2 minutes or until the edges start to curl and the surface is dry.
Loosen the dosa with a spatula and flip it over; cook for another minute or until the other side is golden brown.
Serve the dosa hot with your favorite chutney or sambar.

name: Double ka meetha
ingredients: Loaf bread, milk
instructions:
Cut the loaf bread into 1-inch thick slices and toast them until they are lightly browned and crispy.
In a large saucepan, boil 2 cups of milk over medium heat until it reduces to half its original quantity and thickens slightly.
Add 1 tablespoon of sugar to the reduced milk and stir until it dissolves completely.
Dip each toasted bread slice into the sweetened milk mixture, coating both sides evenly.
Place the milk-coated bread slices on a serving plate or tray, overlapping them slightly to form a single layer.
Pour the remaining sweetened milk mixture over the bread slices, making sure they are completely saturated.
Refrigerate the Double ka Meetha for at least 30 minutes to allow the bread to absorb the milk mixture.
Serve the Double ka Meetha chilled, garnished with chopped nuts or dried fruits if desired.

name: Dudhi halwa
ingredients: Bottle gourd, green, raisins, sugar, clarified butter
instructions:
Peel and grate the bottle gourd, then squeeze out as much water as possible from the grated gourd using a cheesecloth or a clean cotton cloth.
Heat 2 tablespoons of clarified butter in a deep pan over medium heat and add the grated bottle gourd to it.
Cook the bottle gourd mixture for about 10-12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it turns light brown and the raw smell disappears.
Add 1 cup of sugar to the pan and mix well with the cooked bottle gourd.
Continue cooking the mixture for another 5-7 minutes, stirring frequently, until the sugar dissolves and the mixture thickens.
Add 1/4 cup of chopped raisins to the pan and mix well with the halwa mixture.
Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until the raisins are well coated with the halwa mixture and it reaches the desired consistency.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the dudhi halwa cool slightly before serving.

name: Dum aloo
ingredients: Baby potatoes, garam masala, cashew nuts, kasuri methi, tomatoes
instructions:
Boil the baby potatoes in salted water until they are half-cooked, then drain the water and set the potatoes aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté the cashew nuts until they are lightly browned.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala to the pan and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add 2 medium-sized chopped tomatoes to the pan and sauté until they are soft and mushy.
Add 1 teaspoon of kasuri methi to the pan and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add the half-cooked baby potatoes to the pan and stir well to combine with the tomato mixture.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the potatoes are fully cooked.
Season with salt to taste, then serve hot.

name: Fara
ingredients: Chana dal, whole wheat flour, arhar dal, white urad dal, garam masala powder
instructions:
Rinse the Chana dal, arhar dal, and white urad dal together and soak them in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the dal mixture into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of whole wheat flour and the ground dal paste, mixing well to form a dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a small ball.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook each fara for 1-2 minutes on each side, until it's lightly browned and cooked through.
Sprinkle a pinch of garam masala powder over each fara while it's still warm.
Serve the fara hot with your favorite accompaniments.

name: Farsi Puri
ingredients: Semolina, clarified butter, oil, white flour, black pepper
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of semolina and 1 cup of white flour.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of black pepper to the flour mixture and mix well.
Gradually add 1/4 cup of clarified butter to the flour mixture and mix until it resembles coarse crumbs.
Add 1/4 cup of oil to the flour mixture and mix until the dough comes together.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium-high heat and fry the puris until they are golden brown and puffed up.
Remove the fried puris from the oil and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve the Farsi Puri warm or at room temperature.

name: Gajar ka halwa
ingredients: Carrots, milk, sugar, ghee, cashews, raisins
instructions:
Peel and grate 2 cups of carrots and set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of ghee in a large pan over medium heat.
Add the grated carrots to the pan and sauté for 5-7 minutes or until they start to soften.
Add 1 cup of milk to the pan and stir well to combine with the carrots.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 20-25 minutes or until the carrots are tender and the milk has thickened.
Add 1 cup of sugar to the pan and stir well to combine with the carrot mixture.
Continue to simmer for another 10-15 minutes or until the halwa has thickened and the sugar has dissolved.
Add 1 tablespoon of ghee to the pan and stir well to combine with the halwa.
Add 1/4 cup of chopped cashews and 1/4 cup of raisins to the pan and stir well to combine with the halwa.
Simmer for an additional 2-3 minutes or until the cashews and raisins are well coated with the halwa.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the gajar ka halwa cool slightly before serving.

name: Galho
ingredients: Rice, axone, salt, water, chillies, pork
instructions:
Wash and soak the rice in water for at least 30 minutes, then drain the water and set the rice aside.
Cut the pork into small pieces and wash them thoroughly, then drain the water and set the pork aside.
Heat 2 cups of water in a large pot over high heat, then add 1 teaspoon of salt and bring to a boil.
Add the pork pieces to the boiling water, reduce the heat to medium, and cook until the pork is tender, about 15-20 minutes.
Add the axone to the pot and stir well to combine, then cook for an additional 5 minutes.
Add 1-2 chopped chillies to the pot, depending on desired spice level, and stir well to combine.
Add the soaked and drained rice to the pot, stirring well to combine with the pork and axone mixture.
Add 2 cups of water to the pot, stirring well to combine, then bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot with a tight-fitting lid, and cook for 15-20 minutes, or until the rice is cooked and the liquid has been absorbed.
Turn off the heat and let the galho rest for 5 minutes before serving hot.

name: Gatta curry
ingredients: Yogurt, besan, sauce, garam masala powder, gram flour
instructions:
In a large bowl, whisk together 1 cup of yogurt and 2 tablespoons of besan until smooth.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder to the yogurt mixture and mix well.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of gram flour to the mixture, whisking continuously to avoid lumps.
Add 1/4 cup of water to the mixture and whisk until it forms a thick, smooth batter.
Cover the bowl with a cloth and let the mixture rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the mixture into small portions and shape each portion into a cylindrical shape.
Boil a large pot of water and add the cylindrical shapes to the pot.
Cook the shapes for 15-20 minutes or until they float to the surface.
Remove the cooked shapes from the pot and let them cool.
Heat 2 tablespoons of sauce in a pan over medium heat.
Add the cooked shapes to the pan and toss them in the sauce until they are well coated.
Serve the Gatta curry hot.

name: Gavvalu
ingredients: Rice flour, sugar, salt, ghee, semolina
instructions:
Heat 1 tablespoon of ghee in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 cup of semolina and roast until it turns light golden brown, stirring constantly.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly.
Add 1 cup of rice flour, 1/2 cup of sugar, and a pinch of salt to the pan and mix well.
Gradually add 1/4 cup of ghee to the mixture and mix until it forms a crumbly texture.
Add 1-2 tablespoons of lukewarm water to the mixture and mix until it forms a smooth dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions and shape each portion into a small ball.
Flatten each ball slightly into a disk shape using a rolling pin or your fingers.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the gavvalu until they are golden brown on both sides.
Serve the gavvalu warm or at room temperature.

name: Gheela Pitha
ingredients: Sticky rice, rice flour, jaggery, orange rind
instructions:
Rinse the sticky rice thoroughly and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the sticky rice into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of rice flour and 1 cup of the ground sticky rice paste.
Add 1/2 cup of grated jaggery to the bowl and mix well until the jaggery is evenly distributed.
Add 1 tablespoon of grated orange rind to the bowl and mix until well combined.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the bowl and mix until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes pliable and smooth.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 1/8 inch thick.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the pithas for 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Serve the Gheela Pitha warm or at room temperature.

name: Ghevar
ingredients: Flour, ghee, kewra, milk, clarified butter, sugar, almonds, pistachio, saffron, green cardamom
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of flour and 1/4 teaspoon of salt, and mix well.
Add 1/4 cup of ghee to the flour mixture and mix until the dough resembles coarse crumbs.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm milk to the dough and knead until a smooth dough forms.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Heat 2-3 inches of ghee in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
When the ghee is hot, add a few drops of kewra essence and mix well.
Flatten each dough ball slightly and add it to the hot ghee, frying until it puffs up and the edges start to curl.
Reduce the heat to low and cook for 5-7 minutes or until the ghevar is golden brown and crispy.
Remove the ghevar from the ghee and place it on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
In a large saucepan, combine 1 cup of sugar, 1 cup of water, and 1/4 teaspoon of saffron threads, and bring to a boil over high heat.
Reduce the heat to medium and cook the syrup for 5-7 minutes or until it reaches a thick, one-string consistency.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of crushed green cardamom to the syrup and mix well.
Dip each ghevar into the hot syrup for 2-3 seconds on each side, coating it evenly.
Place the syrup-coated ghevar on a wire rack to drain excess syrup.
Melt 2 tablespoons of clarified butter in a small saucepan over low heat.
Add 1 tablespoon of sliced almonds and 1 tablespoon of sliced pistachio to the melted butter and mix well.
Drizzle the nut mixture over the ghevar and serve warm.

name: Ghooghra
ingredients: Dry fruits, semolina, all purpose flour
instructions:
Roast the semolina in a pan over medium heat, stirring frequently, until it turns light golden brown.
Remove the roasted semolina from the pan and set it aside to cool.
In the same pan, add a small amount of ghee or oil and sauté the dry fruits until they are lightly toasted.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the roasted semolina, sautéed dry fruits, and all-purpose flour.
Mix the ingredients well until they are evenly distributed.
Gradually add a small amount of ghee or oil to the mixture and mix until it forms a crumbly dough.
Knead the dough for about 5 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions, about the size of a small lemon.
Shape each portion into a round ball and then flatten it slightly into a disk shape.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the ghooghra disks for about 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are lightly browned and crispy.
Serve the ghooghra warm or at room temperature.

name: Goja
ingredients: Baking soda, clarified butter, oil, all purpose flour
instructions:
Preheat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add 2 tablespoons of oil to it.
Once the oil is hot, add 1 tablespoon of clarified butter to the pan and let it melt.
In a small bowl, mix 1 teaspoon of baking soda with 2 tablespoons of all-purpose flour.
Add the flour mixture to the pan and stir well to combine with the oil and butter.
Cook the mixture for about 5 minutes, stirring constantly, until it turns light brown and has a nutty aroma.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the Goja cool completely before serving.

name: Gud papdi
ingredients: Wheat flour, jaggery, clarified butter, sliced almonds
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of wheat flour and 1/2 cup of grated jaggery, mixing well until the jaggery is evenly distributed throughout the flour.
Add 1/4 cup of clarified butter to the flour mixture and mix until the dough comes together and forms a ball.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook each papdi for 30-45 seconds on each side, until it is lightly browned and crispy.
Brush each papdi with a little clarified butter while it is still warm.
Sprinkle a few sliced almonds over each papdi and serve warm.

name: Gulab jamun
ingredients: Milk powder, plain flour, baking powder, ghee, milk, sugar, water, rose water
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of milk powder, 1/2 cup of plain flour, and 1/4 teaspoon of baking powder.
Add 1/4 cup of ghee to the dry ingredients and mix until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm milk to the mixture and knead until a smooth dough forms.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Heat enough oil in a deep frying pan to deep-fry the dumplings, and when the oil is hot, add the dumplings and fry until they are golden brown.
Remove the fried dumplings from the oil with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
In a large saucepan, combine 1 cup of sugar, 1 cup of water, and 1 tablespoon of rose water, and bring to a boil over high heat.
