Reduce the heat to medium and simmer the syrup for 5 minutes or until it thickens slightly.
Add the fried dumplings to the syrup and simmer for another 5 minutes or until they are fully coated with the syrup.
Remove the saucepan from the heat and let the gulab jamun cool to room temperature.
Serve the gulab jamun warm or at room temperature, garnished with chopped pistachios or almonds if desired.

name: Halvasan
ingredients: Whole wheat rava, chia seed, lemon, edible gum, litre milk
instructions:
Rinse the whole wheat rava in a fine mesh sieve until the water runs clear, then drain and set aside.
In a large saucepan, combine 1 litre of milk and bring to a boil over high heat, stirring occasionally.
Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer the milk for 10-12 minutes, or until it thickens and reduces slightly.
Add the rinsed whole wheat rava to the saucepan and cook for an additional 5-7 minutes, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens and the rava is fully cooked.
Remove the saucepan from the heat and stir in 1 tablespoon of chia seeds, allowing them to absorb the mixture for 2-3 minutes.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of edible gum to the mixture and stir well to combine.
Squeeze the juice of 1 lemon into the mixture and stir until fully incorporated.
Allow the halvasan to cool to room temperature, then refrigerate for at least 2 hours or until chilled.
Once chilled, scoop the halvasan into individual serving cups or a large serving dish and serve.

name: Hando Guri
ingredients: Jaggery, raisins
instructions:
Grate 1 cup of jaggery into a large mixing bowl.
Add 1/2 cup of raisins to the bowl and mix well until the raisins are evenly coated with the grated jaggery.
Knead the mixture with your hands for about 5 minutes until it forms a smooth and sticky dough.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions, about the size of a small lemon.
Shape each portion into a round ball and flatten it slightly into a disk shape.
Serve the Hando Guri immediately, or store them in an airtight container for up to 2 days.

name: Handwo
ingredients: Bottle gourd, chana dal, cabbage, urad dal, toor dal
instructions:
Peel and grate the bottle gourd and set it aside.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté the chopped cabbage until it's translucent.
Add the chana dal, urad dal, and toor dal to the pan and roast them until they're lightly browned.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring the mixture to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let the mixture simmer for 10-12 minutes or until the dals are cooked.
Add the grated bottle gourd to the pan and stir well to combine.
Cook for an additional 5-7 minutes or until the bottle gourd is cooked through and the mixture has thickened.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly.
Using your hands, shape the mixture into small, round patties, about 1-2 inches in diameter.
Serve the handwo warm or at room temperature.

name: Haq Maas
ingredients: Lamb, garam masala powder, curd, turmeric, bay leaf
instructions:
In a large bowl, mix together 1 cup of curd, 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder, and 1/2 teaspoon of turmeric powder.
Add 500 grams of lamb pieces to the bowl and mix well to coat the lamb evenly with the curd mixture.
Cover the bowl with a lid and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or overnight to marinate the lamb.
Remove the lamb from the refrigerator and let it sit at room temperature for 30 minutes.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat and add 2 bay leaves to the pan.
Once the bay leaves start to sizzle, add the marinated lamb pieces to the pan and sauté until they are browned on all sides.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan, cover with a lid, and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and simmer for 1 1/2 hours, or until the lamb is tender and the gravy has thickened.
Serve the Haq Maas hot, garnished with additional bay leaves if desired.

name: Idiappam
ingredients: Rice flour, hot water, grated coconut
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of rice flour and a pinch of salt.
Gradually add in 1 cup of hot water to the rice flour mixture and mix well until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes pliable and soft.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 4-6 equal portions, depending on how thick you want your idiappam to be.
Shape each portion into a long rope-like shape.
Hold one end of the rope and start to press it through a idiappam maker or a metal sieve with large holes to create the idiappam strings.
Collect the idiappam strings on a plate or a clean cloth.
Sprinkle a few grated coconut flakes over the idiappam strings and gently mix well.
Repeat the process with the remaining dough portions and serve the idiappam hot with your favorite curry or stew.

name: Idli
ingredients: Split urad dal, urad dal, idli rice, thick poha, rock salt
instructions:
Rinse the idli rice and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water from the soaked idli rice and grind it into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
Rinse the split urad dal and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water from the soaked split urad dal and grind it into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
Add the urad dal to the grinder or blender and grind it into a smooth paste along with the split urad dal.
Add the thick poha to the grinder or blender and grind it into a smooth paste along with the urad dal mixture.
Add rock salt to the grinder or blender and grind it into a smooth paste along with the urad dal mixture.
Mix the ground idli rice paste with the urad dal mixture and mix well until it forms a smooth and thick batter.
Transfer the batter to a large vessel or container and let it ferment in a warm place for 12-15 hours or overnight.
Once the batter has fermented, mix it well and scoop out the required amount into idli molds or small cups.
Steam the idlis in a steamer or pressure cooker for 10-12 minutes or until they are cooked and soft.
Remove the idlis from the molds or cups and serve hot with chutney or sambar.

name: Imarti
ingredients: Sugar syrup, lentil flour
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of lentil flour and a pinch of salt, mixing well to combine.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the flour mixture, kneading until a smooth dough forms.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions, about the size of a small lemon.
Roll out each portion into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the rolled-out dough circles for 30 seconds on each side.
Remove the cooked circles from the pan and immediately soak them in the sugar syrup for about 30 seconds on each side.
Remove the imarti from the syrup and place them on a wire rack to drain excess syrup.
Serve the imarti warm or at room temperature, garnished with chopped nuts or dried fruit if desired.

name: Jalebi
ingredients: Maida, corn flour, baking soda, vinegar, curd, water, turmeric, saffron, cardamom
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of maida, 1 tablespoon of corn flour, and 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of turmeric powder, a few strands of saffron, and 1/4 teaspoon of cardamom powder to the dry ingredients and mix well.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of curd to the dry ingredients and mix until a smooth batter forms.
Add 1/2 cup of water to the batter and mix until it reaches a thick but pourable consistency.
Cover the bowl with a damp cloth and let the batter ferment in a warm place for 24 hours.
After fermentation, add 1/2 teaspoon of vinegar to the batter and mix well.
Heat enough oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat for deep-frying.
Using a piping bag or a plastic bottle with a small hole, pour the fermented batter into the hot oil in circular motions.
Fry the jalebis until they are golden brown, then drain them on paper towels.
Soak the fried jalebis in a sugar syrup of your choice for at least 30 minutes before serving.

name: Jeera Aloo
ingredients: Green chilies, lemon juice, chili powder, boiled potatoes
instructions:
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté the green chilies until they start to change color.
Add the boiled potatoes to the pan and stir well to combine with the green chilies.
Sprinkle chili powder over the potatoes and stir well to coat evenly.
Squeeze lemon juice over the potatoes and stir well to combine.
Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, stirring frequently, until the flavors have melded together and the potatoes are well coated.
Serve hot, garnished with additional green chilies if desired.

name: Kaara kozhambu
ingredients: Sesame oil, drumstick, tamarind paste, sambar powder, tomato
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of sesame oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 2-3 drumsticks, cut into 1-inch pieces, to the pan and sauté until they start to brown.
Add 1 medium-sized tomato, diced, to the pan and sauté until it becomes soft and mushy.
Add 1 teaspoon of sambar powder to the pan and sauté for 1 minute, until the powder is fragrant.
Add 2 tablespoons of tamarind paste to the pan and sauté for 1 minute, until the paste is well combined with the spices.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring the mixture to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let the kozhambu simmer for 10-15 minutes, or until the drumsticks are cooked through and the sauce has thickened.
Season the kozhambu with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Kabiraji
ingredients: Fish fillet, besan, lemon, mint, ginger
instructions:
Cut the fish fillet into small pieces and wash them thoroughly under cold water, then pat them dry with a paper towel.
In a bowl, mix together 1/2 cup of besan, 1 tablespoon of lemon juice, 1 tablespoon of chopped mint, and 1 tablespoon of grated ginger to make a thick paste.
Add a pinch of salt to the besan mixture and mix well.
Dip each piece of fish into the besan mixture, coating it evenly on all sides, and place them on a plate or tray.
Heat about 2-3 inches of oil in a deep frying pan over medium-high heat until it reaches 350°F.
When the oil is hot, carefully slide in 3-4 pieces of the coated fish into the oil, do not overcrowd the pan.
Fry the fish for about 3-4 minutes on each side, or until they are golden brown and crispy.
Remove the fried fish from the oil with a slotted spoon and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve the Kabiraji hot and enjoy!

name: Kachori
ingredients: Moong dal, rava, garam masala, dough, fennel seeds
instructions:
Soak moong dal in water for at least 4 hours or overnight, then drain and grind it into a coarse paste.
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat and add fennel seeds, sautéing until fragrant.
Add the ground moong dal paste to the pan and sauté for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder to the pan and mix well.
Add 1 tablespoon of rava to the pan and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Remove the pan from heat and let the mixture cool completely.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and roll each portion into a ball.
Flatten each dough ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Place 1-2 teaspoons of the cooled moong dal mixture in the center of each dough circle.
Fold the dough over the filling to form a half-moon shape, and press the edges together to seal the kachori.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium-high heat and fry the kachoris until golden brown, about 3-4 minutes on each side.
Remove the fried kachoris from the oil and drain on paper towels.

name: Kadai paneer
ingredients: Cottage cheese, bell peppers, gravy, garam masala, cashew nuts
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of garam masala, letting it sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 1 cup of diced bell peppers to the pan and sauté until they start to soften, about 2-3 minutes.
Add 1 cup of cottage cheese cubes to the pan and cook until they start to brown, about 3-4 minutes.
Add 1/2 cup of cashew nuts to the pan and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Pour in 1 cup of prepared gravy into the pan, stirring well to combine with the cottage cheese and bell peppers.
Reduce heat to low and let the mixture simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sauce has thickened and the flavors have melded together.
Season with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Kadhi pakoda
ingredients: Besan, garam masala powder, gram flour, ginger, curry leaves
instructions:
In a large bowl, mix 1 cup of gram flour with 1/2 teaspoon of garam masala powder and a pinch of salt.
Add 1/4 cup of water to the bowl and mix until a smooth batter forms.
Finely chop 1-inch piece of ginger and add it to the batter, mixing well.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat and using a spoon, drop small portions of the batter into the oil to form pakodas.
Fry the pakodas until they are golden brown and crispy, then remove them from the oil with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
In a large pan, heat 2 tablespoons of oil over medium heat and add 5-6 curry leaves, letting them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let simmer for 5 minutes.
Add the fried pakodas to the simmering water and let them cook for 5-7 minutes or until they are fully coated in the kadhi.
In a small bowl, mix 2 tablespoons of besan with 1 tablespoon of water to form a smooth paste, then add it to the kadhi and stir well.
Continue to simmer the kadhi for another 5 minutes or until it thickens, then serve hot.

name: Kajjikaya
ingredients: Rice flour, jaggery, coconut
instructions:
Dry roast the rice flour in a pan over low heat, stirring constantly, until it turns light brown and fragrant.
Remove the roasted rice flour from the pan and set it aside to cool.
Grate the coconut using a grater or a food processor until it is finely shredded.
Melt the jaggery in a pan over low heat, stirring occasionally, until it dissolves completely.
Add the grated coconut to the melted jaggery and mix well until the coconut is evenly coated.
Add the cooled roasted rice flour to the coconut-jaggery mixture and mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for about 5 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 1/8 inch thick.
Heat a non-stick pan or a cast-iron skillet over medium heat.
Cook the flattened dough circles in the pan for about 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Remove the cooked kajjikaya from the pan and let them cool on a wire rack.

name: Kaju katli
ingredients: Cashews, ghee, cardamom, sugar
instructions:
Roast 1 cup of cashews in a pan over medium heat, stirring constantly, until they turn light golden brown and fragrant.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the cashews cool down completely.
Grind the cooled cashews into a fine powder using a blender or food processor.
In a large pan, combine 1 cup of sugar and 1/2 cup of water over medium heat, stirring until the sugar dissolves.
Bring the sugar syrup to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 5-7 minutes, or until the syrup reaches a thread-like consistency.
Add 1 tablespoon of ghee to the sugar syrup and mix well.
Add the ground cashews to the sugar syrup and mix until a smooth dough forms.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of crushed cardamom to the dough and mix well.
Knead the dough for 2-3 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 10-15 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions and shape each portion into a thin diamond or square shape.
Serve the kaju katli fresh, or store them in an airtight container for up to 5 days.

name: Kakinada khaja
ingredients: Wheat flour, sugar
instructions:
Mix 1 cup of wheat flour with 1/2 cup of sugar in a large bowl until the sugar is evenly distributed.
Gradually add water to the mixture and knead it into a smooth dough for about 10 minutes.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and place a rolled-out dough circle in the pan.
Cook the khaja for 30 seconds on the first side, then flip it over and cook for another 30 seconds.
Repeat the process with the remaining dough balls.
Once the khajas are cooked, let them cool completely on a wire rack.
Store the khajas in an airtight container for up to 2 days.

name: Kalakand
ingredients: Milk, cottage cheese, sugar
instructions:
Boil 1 liter of milk in a large pan over high heat, stirring occasionally, until it reduces to half its original quantity.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly, until it reaches a temperature of around 80°C to 90°C.
Add 250 grams of cottage cheese to the pan and mix well until it is fully dissolved and the mixture is smooth.
Add 250 grams of sugar to the pan and mix well until it is fully dissolved and the mixture is smooth.
Return the pan to medium heat and cook, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens and reaches a consistency similar to that of soft dough.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly, until it reaches a temperature of around 50°C to 60°C.
Knead the mixture with your hands until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Shape the mixture into small squares or diamonds and let them cool to room temperature.
Refrigerate the kalakand for at least 2 hours before serving.

name: Kanji
ingredients: Carrot, yellow mustard, red chilli, black salt
instructions:
Grate 1 large carrot and set it aside.
In a blender or grinder, combine 1/2 teaspoon yellow mustard seeds, 1-2 red chillies (depending on desired spiciness), and 1/2 teaspoon black salt.
Blend the mixture into a smooth paste, adding a little water if necessary.
In a large bowl, combine the grated carrot and the blended paste.
Mix well until the carrot is evenly coated with the spice paste.
Add 1 cup of water to the bowl and mix until the mixture is well combined.
Transfer the mixture to a large pot and bring it to a boil over high heat.
Reduce the heat to low and simmer the kanji for 10-15 minutes or until it thickens slightly.
Remove the pot from the heat and let the kanji cool to room temperature.
Refrigerate the kanji for at least 2 hours or overnight before serving.

name: Kansar
ingredients: Wheat flour, cashews, rapeseed oil
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of wheat flour and a pinch of salt.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of rapeseed oil to the flour mixture and mix until it resembles coarse crumbs.
Add 1/2 cup of chopped cashews to the mixture and mix well.
Knead the mixture for 5-7 minutes until it forms a smooth dough.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook each circle for 1-2 minutes on each side, until it turns golden brown.
Brush the cooked Kansar with a little rapeseed oil and serve hot.

name: Karela bharta
ingredients: Bitter gourd, fennel, garam masala powder, chili powder, amchur powder
instructions:
Roast 2-3 bitter gourds over an open flame or in a preheated oven at 400°F (200°C) for 10-15 minutes, or until the skin is charred and blistered.
Remove the bitter gourds from the heat and let them cool down, then peel off the skin and scoop out the seeds and pulp.
Mash the roasted bitter gourd flesh in a bowl using a fork or potato masher until it's smooth and pulpy.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté 1 teaspoon of fennel seeds until they sizzle and fragrant.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and 1 teaspoon of amchur powder to the pan and sauté for 1 minute, stirring constantly.
Add the mashed bitter gourd to the pan and stir well to combine with the spice mixture.
Cook the bitter gourd mixture for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it's dry and the flavors are well combined.
Season with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Keerai kootu
ingredients: Moong dal, chana dal, spinach, urad dal, coconut oil
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of coconut oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of urad dal and let it turn golden brown, stirring frequently.
Add 1/2 cup of moong dal and 1/2 cup of chana dal, and sauté for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add 2 cups of fresh spinach leaves and sauté until they wilt, about 3-4 minutes.
Add 2 cups of water and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the dal is cooked.
Mash the dal mixture using a potato masher or a spoon to desired consistency.
Season with salt to taste, and serve hot.

name: Keerai masiyal
ingredients: Urad dal, curry leaves, sugar, mustard seeds, spinach
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of urad dal and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the soaked urad dal and grind it into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add 10-12 curry leaves to the pan and sauté until they are fragrant and slightly browned.
Add 2 cups of fresh spinach leaves to the pan and sauté until they are wilted.
Add the ground urad dal paste to the pan and stir well to combine with the spinach mixture.
Add 1 teaspoon of sugar to the pan and stir well to combine.
Cook the mixture for 5-7 minutes or until the urad dal is cooked and the mixture is dry and thick.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the keerai masiyal cool to room temperature.
Serve the keerai masiyal with rice or roti.

name: Keerai poriyal
ingredients: Amaranth leaves, split urad dal, mustard seeds, grated coconut, red chili
instructions:
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 1/2 cup of split urad dal and sauté until it turns light golden brown.
Add 2 cups of chopped Amaranth leaves and sauté until they start to wilt.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt and mix well.
Add 1/4 cup of grated coconut and sauté for another 2-3 minutes.
Add 1-2 red chilies, chopped, and sauté for another minute.
Stir well to combine all the ingredients and cook for an additional 2-3 minutes or until the leaves are fully cooked.
Remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Keerai sadam
ingredients: Greens, tomato, mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds
instructions:
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat and add mustard seeds and fenugreek seeds, letting them splutter for a few seconds.
Add chopped tomatoes to the pan and sauté until they are soft and mushy.
Add a handful of washed and chopped greens to the pan and stir well to combine with the tomato mixture.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let the mixture simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the greens are cooked and the water has reduced.
Mash the cooked greens mixture with a spoon or potato masher to desired consistency.
Serve the keerai sadam hot with steaming rice.

name: Keri no ras
ingredients: Mango, sugar
instructions:
Wash and dry the mango thoroughly, then peel and chop it into small pieces.
In a large bowl, combine the chopped mango and sugar.
Mix the mango and sugar together until the sugar is evenly distributed and the mango is well coated.
Cover the bowl with a cloth or plastic wrap and let it sit at room temperature for at least 2 hours or overnight in the refrigerator.
After the sitting time, mash the mango mixture with a potato masher or a fork until it reaches your desired consistency.
Transfer the mixture to an airtight container and store it in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

name: Khakhra
ingredients: Whole wheat flour, low fat, bengal gram flour
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of whole wheat flour and 1/2 cup of Bengal gram flour.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the flour mixture and knead for 5-7 minutes until a smooth dough forms.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter, using a rolling pin.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and place a khakhra on it.
Cook the khakhra for 30 seconds, then flip it over and cook for another 30 seconds, until it starts to puff up and the edges start to curl.
Flip the khakhra again and cook for another 30 seconds, until it is crispy and golden brown.
Repeat the process with the remaining dough portions.
Once cooked, let the khakhras cool completely on a wire rack before storing them in an airtight container.

name: Khaman
ingredients: Yogurt, fresh coconut, sesame seeds, semolina, gram flour
instructions:
In a large bowl, mix together 1 cup of semolina and 1/2 cup of gram flour.
Add 1/2 cup of yogurt to the bowl and mix until the mixture forms a smooth batter.
Grate 1/2 cup of fresh coconut and add it to the bowl, mixing well.
Add 1 tablespoon of sesame seeds to the bowl and mix until they are evenly distributed.
Cover the bowl with a cloth and let the mixture ferment in a warm place for 2-3 hours or until it has doubled in volume.
Preheat a non-stick pan over medium heat and grease it with a small amount of oil.
Using a ladle, pour a small amount of the fermented mixture into the pan and spread it evenly to form a circular shape.
Cook the khaman for 2-3 minutes or until the edges start to curl and the surface is dry.
Loosen the khaman with a spatula and flip it over, cooking for another 1-2 minutes or until it is golden brown.
Repeat the process with the remaining mixture, greasing the pan with oil as needed.
Serve the khaman hot with your favorite chutney or tea.

name: Khandvi
ingredients: Green chili paste, white sesame seeds, gram flour, curry leaves, green chili
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of gram flour and 1/2 cup of water to form a smooth batter, making sure to remove any lumps.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of green chili paste to the batter and mix well.
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a small pan over medium heat and add 5-6 curry leaves, letting them sizzle for a few seconds.
Pour the gram flour batter into the pan with the curry leaves and cook, stirring continuously, until the mixture thickens and leaves the sides of the pan.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the mixture cool slightly.
Pour the mixture onto a greased surface, such as a granite or marble countertop, and spread it evenly to form a thin layer.
Sprinkle 1/4 teaspoon of white sesame seeds over the mixture and let it cool and set completely.
Once set, use a sharp knife or a khandvi cutter to cut the mixture into desired shapes and sizes.
Serve the khandvi garnished with chopped green chili and a sprinkle of white sesame seeds, if desired.

name: Khar
ingredients: Raw papaya, panch phoran masala, nigella seeds, mustard oil, fennel seeds
instructions:
Peel and grate 1 large raw papaya and set it aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of mustard oil in a deep pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of panch phoran masala and let it sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 1 teaspoon of nigella seeds and let them crackle for a few seconds.
Add 1 teaspoon of fennel seeds and let them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add the grated raw papaya to the pan and stir well to combine with the spice mixture.
Cook the papaya mixture for about 10-12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it is dry and the papaya is cooked through.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the Khar cool to room temperature.
Once cooled, store the Khar in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

name: Kheer
ingredients: Milk, rice, sugar, dried fruits
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the rice into a coarse paste using a blender or grinder.
In a large, heavy-bottomed pan, combine 3 cups of milk and the ground rice paste.
Place the pan over medium heat and cook, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens and the rice is fully cooked.
Add 1 cup of sugar to the pan and stir until it is fully dissolved.
Reduce the heat to low and simmer the mixture for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it thickens further.
Add 1/2 cup of dried fruits, such as raisins, almonds, and pistachios, to the pan and stir gently to combine.
Continue to simmer the kheer for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the flavors have melded together and the mixture has thickened to your liking.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the kheer cool to room temperature.
Refrigerate the kheer for at least 2 hours or overnight before serving chilled.

name: Kheer sagar
ingredients: Chenna, condensed milk, sugar, saffron, cardamom
instructions:
Boil 1 liter of water in a large pan and add 1/2 teaspoon of saffron threads to it, letting it steep for 5 minutes to infuse the flavor and color.
In a blender or food processor, blend 250 grams of chenna until it becomes smooth and creamy.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the blended chenna, 1 can of condensed milk, and 1/2 cup of sugar, mixing well until the sugar is fully dissolved.
Add the saffron-infused water to the chenna mixture and mix well to combine.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of ground cardamom to the mixture and mix well to combine.
Pour the mixture into small individual serving cups or ramekins.
Refrigerate the kheer sagar for at least 2 hours or overnight to allow it to chill and set.
Serve the kheer sagar chilled, garnished with a sprinkle of saffron threads and a few chopped nuts, if desired.

name: Khichdi
ingredients: Moong dal, green peas, ginger, tomato, green chili
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of moong dal and soak it in water for 30 minutes, then drain the water and set it aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pressure cooker over medium heat.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger and sauté until it turns light brown.
Add 1 chopped tomato and sauté until it becomes soft and mushy.
Add 1-2 chopped green chilies and sauté for another minute.
Add 1 cup of green peas and sauté for 2-3 minutes until they are tender.
Add the soaked and drained moong dal, 4 cups of water, and salt to taste to the pressure cooker.
Close the lid of the pressure cooker and cook for 3-4 whistles or until the dal is cooked and mushy.
Let the pressure release naturally, then open the lid and mash the khichdi slightly with a spoon.
Serve the khichdi hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Khichu
ingredients: Rice flour, sesame seeds, baking soda, peanut oil
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of rice flour and 1 teaspoon of baking soda.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the bowl and mix until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 10 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a small ball.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat 1 tablespoon of peanut oil in a non-stick pan over medium heat.
Place a flattened dough circle in the pan and sprinkle a few sesame seeds on top.
Cook the khichu for 1-2 minutes or until the edges start to curl and the surface is dry.
Flip the khichu over and cook for another 1 minute or until it is golden brown.
Repeat the process with the remaining dough portions.
Serve the khichu hot with your favorite accompaniments.

name: Khorisa
ingredients: Fermented bamboo shoot, potato, ginger, green, mustard oil
instructions:
Peel and dice the potatoes into small cubes and set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of mustard oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger to the pan and sauté until fragrant.
Add the diced potatoes to the pan and sauté for 5 minutes or until they start to brown.
Add 1 cup of fermented bamboo shoot to the pan and stir well to combine.
Reduce heat to low and let the mixture simmer for 10-12 minutes or until the potatoes are cooked through.
Stir in 1 tablespoon of chopped green chilies and season with salt to taste.
Serve the Khorisa hot, garnished with additional green chilies if desired.

name: Kofta
ingredients: Paneer, potato, cream, corn flour, garam masala
instructions:
Boil the diced potatoes until they are soft and mash them in a bowl.
Crumble the paneer into the bowl with the mashed potatoes and mix well.
Add 1 tablespoon of corn flour to the bowl and mix until the mixture is smooth and free of lumps.
Add 1 tablespoon of cream to the bowl and mix until the mixture is well combined.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala to the bowl and mix well.
Divide the mixture into 6-8 portions, depending on the desired size of the koftas.
Shape each portion into a round ball and then flatten it slightly into an oval shape.
Heat a non-stick pan with a little oil over medium heat and when hot, add the koftas.
Cook the koftas for 3-4 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and cooked through.
Remove the koftas from the pan and serve hot with your favorite sauce or chutney.

name: Koldil Chicken
ingredients: Banana flower, chicken, green chili, mustard oil, lemon juice
instructions:
Cut the banana flower into small pieces and soak them in water for 30 minutes to remove bitterness.
Drain the water and squeeze out the excess water from the banana flower pieces.
Heat 2 tablespoons of mustard oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1-2 green chilies, chopped, to the pan and sauté until fragrant.
Add 1 pound boneless, skinless chicken to the pan and cook until browned on all sides.
Add the drained banana flower pieces to the pan and stir well to combine with the chicken.
Squeeze 1 tablespoon of fresh lemon juice over the chicken and banana flower mixture.
Season with salt to taste, then cover the pan and cook for 10-15 minutes or until the chicken is cooked through.
Serve hot, garnished with additional green chilies if desired.

name: Koldil Duck
ingredients: Rice flour, mutton, banana, gram flour, olive oil, baking powder
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of rice flour and 1 cup of gram flour.
Add 1 teaspoon of baking powder to the flour mixture and mix well.
In a separate pan, heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil over medium heat.
Add 1 pound of diced mutton to the pan and cook until browned, about 5 minutes.
Add 1 diced banana to the pan and cook for an additional 2 minutes.
Add the cooked mutton and banana mixture to the flour mixture and mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Divide the dough into 6-8 portions, depending on desired size.
Shape each portion into a ball and flatten slightly into a disk shape.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the disks for 3-4 minutes on each side, until golden brown.
Serve the Koldil Duck hot with your choice of sides.

name: Kolim Jawla
ingredients: Baingan, fish, coconut oil, fresh coconut, ginger
instructions:
Cut the Baingan into small pieces and set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of coconut oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger to the pan and sauté until fragrant.
Add the fish pieces to the pan and cook until they are half-done.
Add the Baingan pieces to the pan and stir well to combine with the fish and ginger.
Grate 1/2 cup of fresh coconut and add it to the pan, stirring well to combine.
Continue cooking for another 5-7 minutes or until the fish is fully cooked and the Baingan is tender.
Season with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Kombdi vade
ingredients: Rice flour, urad dal, wheat flour, gram flour, turmeric
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of rice flour, 1 cup of urad dal, 1/2 cup of wheat flour, and 1/2 cup of gram flour.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of turmeric powder to the flour mixture and mix well.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the mixture and mix until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat and fry the vade until they are golden brown and crispy.
Remove the fried vade from the oil and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve the kombdi vade hot with your favorite chutney or raita.

name: Konir Dom
ingredients: Aloo, tomatoes, mustard oil, bay leaf, cinnamon stick
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of mustard oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1 bay leaf and 1 cinnamon stick to the pan and let them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 2-3 diced Aloo (potatoes) to the pan and sauté until they are golden brown, about 5-7 minutes.
Add 2 diced tomatoes to the pan and sauté for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Reduce heat to low and let the mixture simmer for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the potatoes are tender and the flavors have melded together.
Remove the bay leaf and cinnamon stick from the pan and discard.
Serve the Konir Dom hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Kootu
ingredients: Chana dal, urad dal, potato, beans, peas
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of chana dal and 1/2 cup of urad dal together, then soak them in water for at least 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the dal mixture into a coarse paste using a blender or grinder.
Peel and dice 1 large potato into small cubes and set aside.
String and cut 1 cup of beans into 1-inch pieces and set aside.
Add 1 cup of peas to the beans and set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add the ground dal mixture to the pan and sauté until it turns light brown, stirring constantly.
Add the diced potato, beans, and peas to the pan, stirring well to combine.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the vegetables are cooked.
Season with salt to taste, then serve hot.

name: Kos kootu
ingredients: Moong dal, chana dal, cabbage, tamarind, curry leaves
instructions:
Rinse the moong dal and chana dal together and soak them in water for at least 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the dal mixture into a coarse paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat and add a few curry leaves to it.
Once the curry leaves are fragrant, add the chopped cabbage to the pan and sauté until it is tender and lightly browned.
Add the ground dal paste to the pan and stir well to combine with the cabbage mixture.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring the mixture to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let the mixture simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the dal is cooked and the mixture has thickened.
Soak a small ball of tamarind in hot water and extract the juice from it.
Add the tamarind juice to the pan and stir well to combine.
Season the kos kootu with salt to taste and serve hot.

name: Koshambri
ingredients: Moong dal, cucumber, curry leaves, green chili, lemon juice
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of moong dal and soak it in water for at least 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the moong dal into a coarse paste using a blender or grinder.
Peel and grate 1 large cucumber and set it aside.
Chop 10-12 curry leaves and 1-2 green chilies finely and mix them together.
Add the curry leaf and green chili mixture to the moong dal paste and mix well.
Add the grated cucumber to the moong dal mixture and mix until everything is well combined.
Squeeze 1-2 tablespoons of lemon juice over the mixture and mix again.
Season with salt to taste, if desired.
Cover and refrigerate the koshambri for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve the koshambri chilled or at room temperature.

name: Koshimbir
ingredients: Cucumber, carrot, tomatoes, cilantro
instructions:
Peel and grate the carrot using a fine grater or a food processor until it's finely shredded.
Peel the cucumber and grate it using a fine grater or a food processor until it's finely shredded.
Chop the tomatoes into small pieces and set aside.
Chop the cilantro leaves finely and set aside.
In a large bowl, combine the grated carrot, grated cucumber, and chopped tomatoes.
Add the chopped cilantro to the bowl and mix well until all the ingredients are fully incorporated.
Season the mixture with salt to taste, and mix well.
Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve the Koshimbir chilled.

name: Kothamali sadam
ingredients: Chana dal, urad dal, gooseberry, raw rice, curry leaves
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of raw rice and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the rice into a fine paste using a blender or grinder.
In a pan, dry roast 1 tablespoon of chana dal and 1 tablespoon of urad dal over medium heat until fragrant.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring to a boil.
Add the ground rice paste to the pan and stir well to combine.
Reduce heat to low and cook for 10-12 minutes, stirring frequently, until the mixture thickens.
Add 1-2 chopped gooseberries to the pan and stir well to combine.
Add a few curry leaves to the pan and stir well to combine.
Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes until the flavors are well combined.
Remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Kulfi falooda
ingredients: Rose syrup, falooda sev, mixed nuts, saffron, sugar
instructions:
In a large bowl, mix 1 cup of milk with 1/2 cup of sugar and 1/4 teaspoon of saffron threads, stirring until the sugar is dissolved and the mixture is well combined.
Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate the mixture for at least 2 hours or overnight to allow the flavors to meld.
Once the mixture is chilled, pour it into an ice cream maker and churn according to the manufacturer's instructions.
While the kulfi is churning, toast the mixed nuts in a dry pan over medium heat, stirring frequently, until they are lightly browned and fragrant.
Once the kulfi is almost fully churned, transfer it to an airtight container and stir in the toasted nuts.
Cover the container with plastic wrap and place it in the freezer to harden for at least 2 hours.
To assemble the falooda, scoop the kulfi into a tall glass or bowl and drizzle with rose syrup.
Sprinkle a handful of falooda sev on top of the kulfi, followed by a sprinkle of toasted nuts.
Repeat the layers one more time, ending with a sprinkle of falooda sev on top.
Serve the kulfi falooda immediately and enjoy!

name: Kumol Sawul
ingredients: Rice, eggs, carrot, beetroot
instructions:
Rinse 2 cups of rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Drain the water and cook the rice in a large pot with 4 cups of fresh water until it's tender and fluffy.
Peel and grate 1 large carrot and 1 large beetroot.
In a large pan, heat 2 tablespoons of oil over medium heat and sauté the grated carrot and beetroot until they're tender and lightly caramelized.
Crack 2 eggs into a bowl and whisk them together with a pinch of salt until well combined.
Add the cooked rice to the bowl with the eggs and mix well until the rice is evenly coated with the egg mixture.
Add the sautéed carrot and beetroot mixture to the bowl and mix until everything is well combined.
Using your hands, shape the mixture into small patties, about 1 1/2 inches in diameter and 1/2 inch thick.
Heat a non-stick pan with a small amount of oil over medium heat and cook the patties until they're golden brown and crispy on both sides.
Serve the Kumol Sawul hot with your favorite dipping sauce.

name: Kutchi dabeli
ingredients: Pav, aloo, peanut, pomegranate, star anise
instructions:
Roast 1-2 star anise pods in a pan over medium heat until fragrant, then grind them into a fine powder using a spice grinder or mortar and pestle.
Boil 2-3 medium-sized potatoes until they are tender, then peel and mash them in a bowl.
Heat 1-2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté 1-2 tablespoons of peanuts until they are lightly browned and fragrant.
Add the mashed potatoes to the pan and stir well to combine with the peanuts and oil.
Add the ground star anise powder to the pan and stir well to combine with the potato-peanut mixture.
Split 4-6 pav buns in half and toast them lightly using a toaster or by grilling them for a few seconds.
Spoon a generous amount of the potato-peanut-star anise mixture onto each pav bun half.
Sprinkle a few seeds of pomegranate over the potato-peanut-star anise mixture on each pav bun half.
Place the other pav bun half on top of each dabeli to create a sandwich.
Serve the Kutchi dabeli hot and enjoy!

name: Kuzhakkattai
ingredients: Sesame oil, raw rice, jaggery, grated coconut
instructions:
Heat 1 tablespoon of sesame oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 cup of raw rice to the pan and roast until it turns light brown, stirring constantly.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the rice cool completely.
Grind the cooled rice into a fine powder using a blender or grinder.
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of grated coconut and 1/2 cup of jaggery powder.
Add the ground rice powder to the bowl and mix well until everything is fully incorporated.
Add 1/4 cup of water to the bowl and mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 1/8 inch thick.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the kuzhakkattai for 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Serve the kuzhakkattai warm or at room temperature.

name: Kuzhambu
ingredients: Pearl onions, urad dal, drumsticks, tomato, curry leaves
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of urad dal and let it sizzle for a few seconds until it turns light brown.
Add 10-12 pearl onions, peeled and chopped, and sauté until they turn translucent.
Add 2 drumsticks, cut into 1-inch pieces, and sauté for 2-3 minutes until they start to soften.
Add 1 medium tomato, chopped, and sauté for another 2-3 minutes until the vegetables are well combined.
Add 2 sprigs of curry leaves and sauté for a few seconds until fragrant.
Add 1 cup of water and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for 10-12 minutes or until the drumsticks are cooked through and the gravy has thickened.
Season with salt to taste.
Remove from heat and serve hot with rice or roti.

name: Kuzhi paniyaram
ingredients: Black lentils, rice
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of black lentils and soak them in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the soaked black lentils into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
Rinse 2 cups of rice and soak them in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the soaked rice into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
Mix the ground lentil paste and rice paste together in a large bowl until well combined.
Add water to the mixture as needed to achieve a thick but pourable batter consistency.
Heat a non-stick kuzhi paniyaram pan or a mini muffin tin over medium heat.
Pour a small amount of the batter into each mold, filling it about 3/4 of the way full.
Cover the pan with a lid and cook for 2-3 minutes or until the edges start to set.
Remove the lid and cook for an additional 1-2 minutes or until the paniyarams are golden brown and cooked through.
Flip the paniyarams over and cook for another 1-2 minutes or until the other side is also golden brown.
Remove the paniyarams from the pan and serve hot with your favorite chutney or sambar.

name: Laapsi
ingredients: Cinnamon, jaggery, clarified butter, dry roasted
instructions:
Dry roast 1 cup of wheat flour in a pan over medium heat, stirring constantly, until it turns light golden brown and fragrant.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the roasted flour cool completely.
Grind the cooled roasted flour into a fine powder using a blender or grinder.
Heat 2 tablespoons of clarified butter in a pan over low heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of ground cinnamon to the melted clarified butter and sauté for a few seconds until fragrant.
Add 1 cup of powdered jaggery to the pan and stir until it dissolves completely.
Add the ground roasted flour to the pan and stir until it is well combined with the jaggery mixture.
Cook the mixture over low heat, stirring constantly, until it turns light golden brown and forms a smooth dough-like consistency.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the mixture cool slightly.
Knead the mixture with your hands until it forms a smooth and pliable dough.
Shape the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon, and serve.

name: Laddu
ingredients: Gram flour, ghee, sugar
instructions:
Roast 1 cup of gram flour in a pan over medium heat, stirring constantly, until it turns light brown and fragrant.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the gram flour cool completely.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the cooled gram flour and 1 cup of sugar, and mix well until the sugar is evenly distributed.
Add 1/4 cup of ghee to the bowl and mix until the mixture forms a crumbly texture.
Gradually add more ghee, 1 tablespoon at a time, to the bowl and mix until the mixture comes together to form a dough.
Knead the dough for about 5 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 10-15 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions, about the size of a small lemon.
Shape each portion into a round ball and then flatten it slightly into a disk shape.
Repeat the process with the remaining dough portions.
Serve the laddus immediately, or store them in an airtight container for up to 5 days.

name: Lassi
ingredients: Yogurt, milk, nuts, sugar
instructions:
In a blender, combine 1 cup of yogurt and 1/2 cup of milk.
Add 1 tablespoon of sugar to the blender and blend until the sugar is fully dissolved.
Add 1/4 cup of chopped nuts to the blender and blend until they are finely chopped and well combined with the yogurt mixture.
Blend the mixture for an additional 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until it is smooth and creamy.
Taste the lassi and add more sugar if desired.
Pour the lassi into glasses and serve immediately.

name: Lauki ke kofte
ingredients: Bottle gourd, garam masala powder, gram flour, ginger, chillies
instructions:
Peel and grate 1 medium-sized bottle gourd and squeeze out as much water as possible from it.
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan and sauté 1-inch piece of grated ginger until it's lightly browned.
Add 1-2 chopped green chillies to the pan and sauté for another minute.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the grated bottle gourd, sautéed ginger and chillies, 1 tablespoon of gram flour, and 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder.
Mix everything well until the gram flour is evenly distributed and the mixture is well combined.
Cover the mixture and let it rest for 10-15 minutes to allow the gram flour to absorb the excess moisture.
Divide the mixture into 6-8 portions, depending on how large you want your kofte to be.
Shape each portion into a round ball and then flatten it slightly into a patty shape.
Heat enough oil in a deep frying pan to deep fry the kofte, and when the oil is hot, add the patties to the pan.
Fry the kofte until they're golden brown and crispy on both sides, which should take around 3-4 minutes per side.
Remove the fried kofte from the oil and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.

name: Lauki ki subji
ingredients: Bottle gourd, coconut oil, garam masala, ginger, green chillies
instructions:
Peel and chop the bottle gourd into small cubes and set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of coconut oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger to the pan and sauté until fragrant for about 1 minute.
Add 2-3 green chillies, chopped, to the pan and sauté for another minute.
Add the chopped bottle gourd cubes to the pan and sauté for about 5 minutes or until they start to soften.
Sprinkle 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder over the bottle gourd and mix well.
Continue to cook the mixture for another 5-7 minutes or until the bottle gourd is tender and cooked through.
Season with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Ledikeni
ingredients: Chhena, sugar, ghee
instructions:
Heat 1 tablespoon of ghee in a non-stick pan over medium heat.
Add 1 cup of chhena to the pan and sauté until it turns light golden brown, stirring constantly.
Add 1 cup of sugar to the pan and mix well with the chhena.
Continue to cook the mixture for about 10 minutes, stirring frequently, until the sugar has dissolved and the mixture has thickened.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the mixture cool slightly.
Knead the mixture with your hands until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Shape the mixture into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Flatten each ball slightly into a disk shape.
Serve the Ledikeni warm or at room temperature.

name: Lilva Kachori
ingredients: Green garlic chutney, fresh green peas, ginger, lemon juice, plain flour
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of plain flour and a pinch of salt, and mix well.
Gradually add lukewarm water to the flour mixture and knead it into a smooth dough, covering it with a damp cloth for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
In a small bowl, mix together 1/4 cup of fresh green peas, 1-inch piece of grated ginger, and 1 tablespoon of lemon juice.
Place 1-2 teaspoons of the green pea mixture in the center of each dough circle.
Fold the dough over the filling to form a half-moon shape, and press the edges together to seal the kachori.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat, and fry the kachoris until they are golden brown and puffed up.
Remove the fried kachoris from the oil and drain excess oil on paper towels.
Serve the Lilva Kachori warm with a dollop of green garlic chutney on the side.

name: Litti chokha
ingredients: Wheat flour, roasted gram flour, tomato, nigella seeds, chilli
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of wheat flour and 1 cup of roasted gram flour.
Gradually add lukewarm water to the flour mixture and knead for 5-7 minutes to form a smooth dough.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Flatten each ball into a small circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the littis for 30-40 seconds on each side, until they are lightly browned.
In a separate pan, heat 2 tablespoons of oil over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of nigella seeds.
Once the nigella seeds start to sizzle, add 1 diced tomato and sauté for 2-3 minutes until the tomato is soft and mushy.
Add 1-2 diced chillies to the pan and sauté for another minute.
Serve the littis with the chokha (tomato and chilli mixture) and enjoy!

name: Luchi
ingredients: Maida, vegetable oil
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of maida and a pinch of salt.
Gradually add lukewarm water to the bowl and mix until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or a deep frying pan over medium heat with enough vegetable oil to deep fry the luchi.
When the oil is hot, carefully slide a rolled-out luchi into the oil and fry until it puffs up and the edges start to curl.
Flip the luchi over and fry for another 30 seconds to 1 minute, until it is golden brown.
Remove the fried luchi from the oil with a slotted spoon and place it on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Repeat the frying process with the remaining dough portions.
Serve the hot luchi with your favorite accompaniment.

name: Lyangcha
ingredients: Flour, fried milk power, sugar syrup
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of flour and 1/2 cup of fried milk powder, mixing well until the mixture is smooth and even.
Gradually add 1/4 cup of sugar syrup to the flour mixture, kneading until a soft dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the lyangcha for 30-45 seconds on each side, until it is lightly browned and puffed up.
Repeat the cooking process with the remaining dough balls.
Serve the lyangcha warm or at room temperature, dusting with additional fried milk powder if desired.

name: Maach Jhol
ingredients: Fish, potol, tomato, chillies, ginger, garlic
instructions:
Cut the fish into small pieces and marinate them with salt and turmeric powder for 15 minutes.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat and fry the fish pieces until they are golden brown and set aside.
In the same pan, add more oil if necessary, and sauté the sliced potol until they are tender and lightly browned.
Add sliced onions, minced garlic, and grated ginger to the pan and sauté until the onions are translucent.
Add chopped tomatoes and green chillies to the pan and sauté until the tomatoes are soft and mushy.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring to a boil.
Add the fried fish pieces to the pan and simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the fish is cooked through.
Season with salt and turmeric powder to taste.
Serve the Maach Jhol hot with steamed rice.

name: Mag Dhokli
ingredients: Moong beans, jaggery, red chillies, oil, salt
instructions:
Rinse the moong beans and soak them in water for at least 4 hours or overnight, then drain and set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat and add 2-3 broken red chillies to it.
Let the chillies sizzle for a few seconds until they start to change color, then add the drained moong beans to the pan.
Stir the moong beans well to coat them with the oil and mix with the chillies, then add 1 cup of water to the pan.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the moong beans are cooked and mushy.
Add 1-2 tablespoons of grated jaggery to the pan and stir well to combine with the moong beans.
Season the mixture with salt to taste, then stir well to combine.
Continue to simmer the mixture for another 5-7 minutes or until the jaggery has dissolved and the flavors have melded together.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the Mag Dhokli cool slightly before serving.

name: Mahim halwa
ingredients: Semolina, sugar
instructions:
Heat a large non-stick pan over medium heat and add 1 cup of semolina, stirring constantly, until it turns light golden brown.
Add 1 cup of sugar to the pan and stir well to combine with the semolina.
Continue cooking for 5-7 minutes, stirring frequently, until the mixture turns a deep golden brown and emits a nutty aroma.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly.
Add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the pan and stir well to combine with the semolina-sugar mixture.
Return the pan to low heat and cook, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens and forms a smooth, creamy consistency.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the mahim halwa cool completely before serving.

name: Makki di roti sarson da saag
ingredients: Palak, makki atta, mustard green, garam masala, ginger
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of makki atta and 1/2 teaspoon of garam masala, and mix well.
Gradually add lukewarm water to the bowl and knead the mixture into a smooth dough, covering it with a damp cloth for 30 minutes.
Meanwhile, chop 1-inch piece of ginger into small pieces and sauté them in a pan with a little oil until fragrant.
Add 2 cups of chopped palak and 1 cup of chopped mustard green to the pan, and sauté until the greens are wilted.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of garam masala to the pan and mix well, then set the saag mixture aside.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions, shape each portion into a ball, and flatten it slightly into a disk shape.
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat, place a disk in the pan, and cook for 1-2 minutes on each side, until it's golden brown and puffed up.
Repeat step 7 with the remaining dough portions, and serve the makki di roti with the sarson da saag.

name: Malapua
ingredients: Yoghurt, refined flour, ghee, fennel seeds
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of yoghurt and 1 tablespoon of ghee, mixing well until the ghee is fully incorporated.
Gradually add 2 cups of refined flour to the bowl, mixing until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes in a warm place.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions, shaping each portion into a ball.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Sprinkle a few fennel seeds in the center of each circle, leaving a 1-inch border around the edges.
Fold the dough over the fennel seeds to form a triangle or a square shape, pressing the edges to seal.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat, and cook the malapua for 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown.
Serve the malapua warm, garnished with additional fennel seeds if desired.

name: Masala Dosa
ingredients: Chana dal, urad dal, potatoes, idli rice, thick poha
instructions:
Rinse and soak 1 cup of idli rice, 1/2 cup of urad dal, and 1/2 cup of chana dal in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the soaked mixture into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
Add 1/2 cup of thick poha to the ground mixture and grind again until well combined.
Transfer the mixture to a large bowl, cover, and let it ferment in a warm place for 12-15 hours or overnight.
Boil 2-3 medium-sized potatoes until they are soft, then peel and mash them in a bowl.
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté the mashed potatoes for 2-3 minutes until they are lightly browned.
Add salt to taste to the potatoes and mix well.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and grease it with a few drops of oil.
Pour a ladleful of the fermented batter onto the pan and spread it evenly to form a circular shape.
Place 1-2 tablespoons of the potato filling in the center of the dosa and fold the dosa in half to enclose the filling.
Cook the dosa for 1-2 minutes until the bottom is golden brown, then flip and cook for another minute.
Serve the masala dosa hot with chutney or sambar of your choice.

name: Masor Koni
ingredients: Fish roe, pumpkin flowers, mustard oil, turmeric, tomato
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of mustard oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of turmeric powder to the oil and let it sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 1 cup of fish roe to the pan and stir well to coat with the turmeric oil mixture.
Add 2-3 pumpkin flowers to the pan and stir gently to combine with the fish roe.
Add 1 diced tomato to the pan and stir well to combine with the fish roe and pumpkin flowers.
Cook for 5-7 minutes or until the fish roe is cooked through and the pumpkin flowers are tender.
Serve the Masor Koni hot, garnished with additional pumpkin flowers if desired.

name: Masor tenga
ingredients: Ridge gourd, fish, lemon, tomatoes, mustard oil
instructions:
Cut the ridge gourd into small pieces and soak them in water for 10 minutes to remove bitterness.
Drain the water and squeeze out the excess water from the ridge gourd pieces.
Heat 2 tablespoons of mustard oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add the fish pieces to the pan and fry until they are golden brown, then remove them from the pan and set aside.
In the same pan, add another tablespoon of mustard oil if necessary, then add the chopped tomatoes and sauté until they are soft and mushy.
Add the ridge gourd pieces to the pan and sauté for 5 minutes or until they start to soften.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for 10 minutes or until the ridge gourd is tender.
Add the fried fish pieces back to the pan and stir gently to combine with the ridge gourd and tomato mixture.
Squeeze the juice of 1 lemon over the curry and stir well to combine.
Season with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Mawa Bati
ingredients: Milk powder, dry fruits, arrowroot powder, all purpose flour
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of milk powder, 1/2 cup of all-purpose flour, and 1/4 cup of arrowroot powder.
Mix the dry ingredients well until they are evenly blended.
Add 1/4 cup of ghee or unsalted butter to the mixture and mix until it resembles coarse crumbs.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the mixture and knead until a smooth dough forms.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Flatten each ball into a disk shape, about 1/4 inch thick.
Place 1-2 teaspoons of chopped dry fruits in the center of each disk.
Fold the dough over the dry fruits to form a triangle or a square shape, and press the edges together to seal the bati.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the batis until they are golden brown on both sides.
Serve the Mawa Batis warm or at room temperature.

name: Methi na Gota
ingredients: Rava, gram flour, lemon juice, turmeric, fenugreek leaves
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of rava and 1/2 cup of gram flour and mix well.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of turmeric powder to the bowl and mix until the spices are evenly distributed.
Add 2 tablespoons of lemon juice to the bowl and mix until the mixture forms a smooth dough.
Wash and chop 1 cup of fresh fenugreek leaves and add them to the bowl, mixing until the leaves are evenly distributed throughout the dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat and when hot, add the dough balls to the pan, a few at a time.
Fry the gotas until they are golden brown, about 3-4 minutes on each side.
Remove the fried gotas from the oil with a slotted spoon and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve the methi na gota hot with your favorite chutney or raita.

name: Mihidana
ingredients: Besan flour, sugar, ghee
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of besan flour and 1/2 cup of sugar and mix well until the sugar is evenly distributed.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of ghee to the bowl and mix until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Gradually add 1/4 cup of ghee to the bowl, mixing continuously until the mixture forms a smooth dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions, about the size of a small marble.
Shape each portion into a smooth ball and then flatten it slightly into a disk shape.
Heat sufficient ghee in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
When the ghee is hot, add the mihidana disks to the pan, being careful not to overcrowd it.
Fry the mihidana until they are golden brown, turning them occasionally to ensure even cooking.
Remove the fried mihidana from the ghee with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
Let the mihidana cool completely before storing them in an airtight container.

name: Mishti Chholar Dal
ingredients: Chana dal, fresh coconut, ginger, cinnamon, raisins
instructions:
Rinse the chana dal and soak it in water for at least 30 minutes, then drain the water and set the dal aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat and sauté the grated ginger until it is lightly browned.
Add 1 cinnamon stick to the pan and sauté for another minute, until fragrant.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring to a boil, then add the soaked and drained chana dal to the pan.
Reduce the heat to low and let the dal simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until it is tender and mushy.
While the dal is cooking, grate 1/2 cup of fresh coconut and set it aside.
Once the dal is cooked, mash it lightly with a spoon or potato masher to create a coarse texture.
Add the grated coconut, 1 tablespoon of raisins, and salt to taste to the pan, and stir well to combine.
Let the mixture simmer for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the flavors have melded together and the dal has thickened slightly.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the Mishti Chholar Dal cool to room temperature before serving.

name: Misi roti
ingredients: Whole wheat flour, chickpea flour, green chilies
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of whole wheat flour and 1/2 cup of chickpea flour.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt and mix well.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the flour mixture and knead for 5-7 minutes until a soft dough forms.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 6-7 inches in diameter.
Place 1-2 green chilies in the center of each circle, depending on desired spiciness.
Fold the dough over the chilies to form a triangle or a square shape, and press the edges to seal.
Heat a non-stick skillet or griddle over medium heat and cook the misi roti for 1-2 minutes on each side, until golden brown.
Serve hot with your favorite accompaniments.

name: Misti doi
ingredients: Milk, jaggery
instructions:
Boil 1 liter of milk in a heavy-bottomed pan over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until it reduces to half its original volume.
Add 1/2 cup of grated jaggery to the reduced milk and stir well to combine.
Continue to cook the mixture over low heat, stirring constantly, until the jaggery dissolves completely and the mixture thickens slightly.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly, until the mixture reaches a temperature of around 40°C to 45°C.
Pour the mixture into small clay pots or ramekins and let it cool to room temperature.
Cover the pots or ramekins with a cloth and refrigerate them for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Serve the misti doi chilled, garnished with a sprinkle of grated jaggery if desired.

name: Modak
ingredients: Rice flour, coconut, jaggery
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of rice flour and a pinch of salt.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the bowl and mix until a soft dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
In a separate pan, heat 1 cup of grated coconut over medium heat, stirring frequently, until it turns light brown.
Add 1 cup of grated jaggery to the pan and stir until it melts and combines with the coconut.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the coconut-jaggery mixture cool to room temperature.
Divide the rested dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Place 1-2 tablespoons of the coconut-jaggery mixture in the center of each circle.
Fold the dough over the filling to form a half-moon shape and press the edges together to seal the modak.
Repeat with the remaining dough and filling to make more modaks.
Steam the modaks in a steamer basket for 10-12 minutes, or until they are cooked through and fluffy.
Serve the modaks warm or at room temperature.

name: Mohanthal
ingredients: Rose water, pistachio, badam, bengal gram flour, saffron
instructions:
Roast 1 cup of bengal gram flour in a pan over low heat, stirring constantly, until it turns light golden brown and fragrant.
Remove the roasted flour from the pan and let it cool completely.
Grind 1/2 cup of badam and 1/4 cup of pistachio into a fine powder using a blender or food processor.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the cooled roasted flour, ground badam-pistachio mixture, and a pinch of saffron threads.
Add 1 tablespoon of ghee to the mixture and mix well until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of rose water to the mixture and mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions, about the size of a small lemon.
Shape each portion into a round ball and then flatten it slightly into a disk shape.
Heat 1-2 tablespoons of ghee in a non-stick pan over medium heat.
Place a few Mohanthal disks in the pan and cook for 3-4 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Repeat the cooking process with the remaining Mohanthal disks.
Let the Mohanthal cool completely on a wire rack before serving.

name: Mushroom do pyaza
ingredients: Mushroom, malai, garam masala, ginger, capsicum
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger and sauté for 1 minute until fragrant.
Add 1 cup of sliced mushrooms and sauté for 3-4 minutes until they start to brown.
Add 1 cup of sliced capsicum and sauté for another 4-5 minutes until both mushrooms and capsicum are tender.
Add 1 tablespoon of malai (or cream) and mix well with the mushroom and capsicum mixture.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder and mix well.
Season with salt to taste, then reduce heat to low and simmer for 2-3 minutes.
Serve hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Mushroom matar
ingredients: Canned coconut milk, frozen green peas, wild mushrooms, garam masala, tomatoes
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala and let it sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 1 cup of sliced wild mushrooms and sauté until they release their moisture and start to brown.
Add 1 cup of diced tomatoes and cook for 2-3 minutes or until they start to break down.
Add 1 cup of frozen green peas and stir well to combine with the mushroom and tomato mixture.
Pour in 1/2 cup of canned coconut milk and stir well to combine.
Reduce heat to low and let the mixture simmer for 5-7 minutes or until the sauce has thickened slightly.
Season with salt to taste, then serve hot.

name: Muthiya
ingredients: Bottle gourd, whole wheat flour, rava, sesame seeds, bengal gram flour
instructions:
Grate 1 large bottle gourd and squeeze out as much water as possible from it.
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup whole wheat flour, 1/2 cup rava, 1/4 cup bengal gram flour, and 1 tablespoon sesame seeds.
Add the grated bottle gourd to the dry ingredients and mix well.
Knead the mixture for about 5 minutes until it forms a smooth dough.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a cylindrical shape.
Heat enough water in a large pot to steam the muthiya, and bring it to a boil.
Reduce the heat to medium, place the muthiya in a steamer basket, and steam them for 15-20 minutes or until they are cooked through.
Remove the muthiya from the steamer and let them cool for a few minutes.
Serve the muthiya hot with your favorite chutney or raita.

name: Mysore pak
ingredients: Besan flour, semolina, mung bean, jaggery, coconut, skimmed milk powder, sugar, ghee
instructions:
Roast the besan flour in a pan over medium heat, stirring constantly, until it turns light brown and fragrant.
Remove the roasted besan flour from the pan and set it aside to cool.
In the same pan, add 1 tablespoon of ghee and roast the semolina over medium heat, stirring constantly, until it turns light brown.
Add the mung bean to the pan and roast for another minute, stirring constantly.
In a separate pan, melt 1 cup of ghee over low heat and add the grated jaggery, stirring until it dissolves completely.
Add the sugar to the pan and stir until it dissolves completely.
Bring the jaggery-sugar mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to medium and simmer for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add the roasted besan flour, semolina, and mung bean mixture to the pan and stir well to combine.
Add 1 cup of coconut gratings to the pan and stir well to combine.
Add 1 tablespoon of skimmed milk powder to the pan and stir well to combine.
Continue to simmer the mixture for another 10-15 minutes, stirring frequently, until it thickens and leaves the sides of the pan.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the mixture cool slightly.
Pour the mixture onto a greased surface, such as a silicone mat or a piece of parchment paper, and spread it evenly to form a square shape.
Let the mixture cool and set at room temperature for at least 30 minutes.
Once set, cut the Mysore pak into desired shapes and sizes.

name: Naan
ingredients: Whole wheat flour, honey, butter, garlic
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 1/2 cups of whole wheat flour and 1/4 teaspoon of salt.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the flour mixture and mix until a soft dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Place the dough in a greased bowl, cover it with a damp cloth, and let it rest in a warm place for 1-2 hours or until it has doubled in size.
Preheat a non-stick skillet or tava over medium heat.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 6-7 inches in diameter.
Brush the surface of each naan with 1/4 teaspoon of melted butter and sprinkle with a pinch of minced garlic.
Place a naan in the preheated skillet and cook for 1-2 minutes or until it starts to puff up and the edges start to curl.
Flip the naan over and cook for another 1-2 minutes or until it is golden brown and cooked through.
Brush the naan with a little water and sprinkle with a pinch of honey.
Repeat the process with the remaining dough portions.

name: Namakpara
ingredients: Wheat flour, baking soda, all purpose flour, black pepper, sunflower oil
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of wheat flour, 1 cup of all-purpose flour, and 1 teaspoon of baking soda.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of black pepper to the flour mixture and mix well.
Gradually add 1/4 cup of sunflower oil to the flour mixture and mix until it resembles coarse crumbs.
Add a small amount of water to the mixture and knead for 5-7 minutes until a smooth dough forms.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the Namakpara for 1-2 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Remove the Namakpara from the pan and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve the Namakpara warm or at room temperature.

name: Nankhatai
