ingredients: Refined flour, besan, ghee, powdered sugar, yoghurt, green cardamom
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C) and line a baking tray with parchment paper.
In a large mixing bowl, whisk together 1 1/2 cups of refined flour and 1/2 cup of besan.
Add 1/4 cup of ghee to the flour mixture and mix until it resembles coarse crumbs.
Add 1/2 cup of powdered sugar to the mixture and mix until well combined.
Add 1/4 cup of yoghurt to the mixture and mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Divide the dough into 12-15 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Flatten each ball slightly into a disk shape using your fingers or a rolling pin.
Place a few pinches of crushed green cardamom in the center of each disk.
Fold the dough over the cardamom to form a triangle or a square shape, and press the edges to seal.
Place the nankhatai on the prepared baking tray, leaving about 1 inch of space between each cookie.
Bake the nankhatai for 15-20 minutes, or until they are lightly golden brown.
Remove the nankhatai from the oven and let them cool on the tray for 5 minutes.
Transfer the nankhatai to a wire rack to cool completely.

name: Navrattan korma
ingredients: Green beans, potatoes, khus khus, low fat, garam masala powder
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of low-fat oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder and sauté for 10 seconds until fragrant.
Add 1 cup of diced potatoes and sauté for 5 minutes until they start to brown.
Add 1 cup of green beans, cut into 1-inch pieces, and sauté for another 5 minutes until they start to soften.
Add 2 tablespoons of khus khus and sauté for 1 minute until it starts to change color.
Add 1 cup of water and bring the mixture to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low, cover the pan, and simmer for 15 minutes until the potatoes and green beans are cooked through.
Serve the Navrattan korma hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Obbattu holige
ingredients: Maida flour, turmeric, coconut, chickpeas, jaggery, ghee, cardamom
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of maida flour and a pinch of turmeric powder.
Gradually add lukewarm water to the bowl and knead the mixture into a smooth dough.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
In a separate pan, dry roast 1 cup of chickpeas over medium heat until they turn light brown.
Grind the roasted chickpeas into a fine powder using a blender or grinder.
In another pan, heat 1 tablespoon of ghee over medium heat and add 1 cup of grated coconut.
Stir the coconut mixture frequently until it turns light brown and fragrant.
Add 1 cup of powdered jaggery to the coconut mixture and stir until it dissolves completely.
Add the ground chickpeas to the coconut-jaggery mixture and stir well.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of cardamom powder to the mixture and stir well.
Divide the rested dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Roll out each dough ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Place 1-2 tablespoons of the coconut-chickpea mixture in the center of each dough circle.
Fold the dough over the filling to form a half-moon shape and press the edges to seal.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the obbattu holige for 1-2 minutes on each side, until they turn golden brown.
Serve the obbattu holige warm or at room temperature.

name: Pachadi
ingredients: Coconut oil, cucumber, curd, curry leaves, mustard seeds
instructions:
Heat 1 tablespoon of coconut oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them sizzle for a few seconds until they start to crackle.
Add a few curry leaves to the pan and sauté for another few seconds until fragrant.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly.
Peel and grate 1 large cucumber and add it to a bowl.
Add the cooled curry leaf and mustard seed mixture to the bowl with the grated cucumber.
Mix in 1 cup of curd into the bowl until well combined.
Refrigerate the mixture for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve the Pachadi chilled.

name: Pakhala
ingredients: Curd, cooked rice, curry leaves, dry chilli
instructions:
In a large bowl, mix 1 cup of curd with 1 cup of cooked rice until the rice is well coated with the curd.
Add 5-6 curry leaves to the bowl and mix well.
Crush 1-2 dry chillies into small pieces and add them to the bowl, mixing until they are evenly distributed.
Mix everything together until the ingredients are well combined.
Cover the bowl with a lid and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve the Pakhala chilled, garnished with additional curry leaves if desired.

name: Palak paneer
ingredients: Cottage cheese, palak, cream, garam masala, butter
instructions:
Blend 1 cup of palak leaves with 1/4 cup of water to make a smooth puree.
Heat 2 tablespoons of butter in a pan over medium heat.
Add the blended palak puree to the pan and sauté for 2-3 minutes or until it thickens slightly.
Add 1/2 cup of cream to the pan and stir well to combine.
Bring the mixture to a simmer and let it cook for 2-3 minutes or until it thickens to your liking.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder to the pan and stir well to combine.
Cut 250 grams of cottage cheese into small cubes and add them to the pan.
Stir gently to combine the cottage cheese with the palak sauce and let it cook for an additional 2-3 minutes or until the cheese is fully coated.
Serve the palak paneer hot, garnished with additional palak leaves if desired.

name: Palathalikalu
ingredients: Rice flour, milk
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of rice flour and slowly add 1/2 cup of milk, mixing well to form a smooth dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the flattened dough circles for 30-45 seconds on each side, until they are lightly browned and cooked through.
Repeat the cooking process with the remaining dough balls.
Serve the palathalikalu warm or at room temperature.

name: Paneer butter masala
ingredients: Paneer, whipping cream, garam masala, cashew nuts, butter
instructions:
Cut the paneer into small cubes and soak them in lukewarm water for 10-15 minutes.
Drain the water and pat the paneer cubes dry with a paper towel to remove excess moisture.
In a blender, grind the cashew nuts into a smooth paste with a little water.
Heat 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pan over medium heat until it melts and starts to foam.
Add the cashew nut paste to the pan and sauté for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until the mixture is lightly browned.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder to the pan and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add 1 cup of whipping cream to the pan and stir well to combine with the cashew nut mixture.
Bring the mixture to a simmer and let it cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it thickens slightly.
Add the paneer cubes to the pan and stir gently to coat them with the creamy sauce.
Reduce the heat to low and let the paneer cook in the sauce for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it is fully coated and heated through.
Serve the paneer butter masala hot, garnished with additional butter and cashew nuts if desired.

name: Paneer tikka masala
ingredients: Paneer, greek yogurt, tandoori masala, cream, bell pepper
instructions:
Cut the paneer into small cubes and place them in a bowl.
In a separate bowl, mix together 1/2 cup of Greek yogurt, 1 teaspoon of tandoori masala, and a pinch of salt.
Add the yogurt mixture to the paneer cubes and mix well to coat, then refrigerate for at least 30 minutes.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a non-stick pan over medium heat.
Remove the paneer from the refrigerator and add it to the pan, cooking until golden brown on all sides, about 5-7 minutes.
Add 1 sliced bell pepper to the pan and cook until tender, about 3-4 minutes.
In a separate saucepan, heat 1 cup of cream over medium heat until it starts to simmer.
Add 1 teaspoon of tandoori masala to the cream and stir to combine.
Add the cooked paneer and bell pepper to the cream sauce and stir to coat.
Reduce heat to low and let simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sauce has thickened slightly.
Serve the paneer tikka masala hot, garnished with fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Pani Pitha
ingredients: Tea leaves, white sesame seeds, dry coconut, soaked rice
instructions:
Drain the soaked rice and grind it into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of tea leaves to it.
Let the tea leaves sizzle for a few seconds until fragrant, then remove them from the pan and set aside.
In the same pan, add 1 tablespoon of white sesame seeds and roast them until they turn light brown.
Add 1 tablespoon of grated dry coconut to the pan and roast for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add the ground rice paste to the pan and stir well to combine with the sesame seeds and coconut mixture.
Cook the mixture for about 5-7 minutes, stirring continuously, until it thickens and forms a smooth dough.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the dough cool slightly.
Knead the dough well until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Divide the dough into small portions and shape each portion into a small ball.
Flatten each ball into a small patty shape, about 1-2 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the pani pithas for about 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.

name: Pani puri
ingredients: Kala chana, mashed potato, boondi, sev, lemon
instructions:
Soak the kala chana overnight and boil them in water until they are soft and mushy.
Drain the water and mash the kala chana in a bowl using a spoon or a masher.
Boil 2-3 medium-sized potatoes until they are soft, then peel and mash them in a separate bowl.
Mix the mashed kala chana and mashed potatoes together in a bowl until well combined.
Fill a small portion of the kala chana-potato mixture into each boondi and set them aside.
Sprinkle a pinch of sev over the filling in each boondi.
Squeeze a few drops of lemon juice over the sev in each boondi.
Serve the pani puri immediately, or store them in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 2 hours before serving.

name: Paniyaram
ingredients: Yogurt, ginger, curry leaves, baking soda, green chilli
instructions:
In a blender, grind together 1-inch piece of ginger, 1 green chilli, and a few curry leaves into a smooth paste.
In a large bowl, whisk together 1 cup of yogurt and the ground paste until well combined.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of baking soda to the yogurt mixture and whisk until smooth.
Cover the bowl with a cloth and let the mixture rest for 30 minutes to allow the baking soda to react.
Heat a non-stick paniyaram pan or a mini muffin tin over medium heat.
Once the pan is hot, pour a small ladleful of the yogurt mixture into each mould, filling it about 3/4 of the way full.
Cook the paniyaram for 2-3 minutes on the first side, until the edges start to curl and the surface is dry.
Flip the paniyaram over and cook for another 1-2 minutes, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Remove the paniyaram from the pan and repeat with the remaining mixture.
Serve the paniyaram hot with chutney or sambar of your choice.

name: Panjeeri
ingredients: Whole wheat flour, musk melon seeds, poppy seeds, edible gum, semolina
instructions:
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add 1 tablespoon of ghee to it.
Add 1 teaspoon of musk melon seeds to the pan and roast them until they turn light brown, stirring frequently.
Add 1 teaspoon of poppy seeds to the pan and roast them for another minute, stirring frequently.
Add 1 teaspoon of edible gum to the pan and roast it for 30 seconds, stirring constantly.
Add 1 cup of whole wheat flour to the pan and roast it for 5-7 minutes, stirring frequently, until it turns light brown and fragrant.
Add 1/2 cup of semolina to the pan and roast it for another 2-3 minutes, stirring frequently, until it turns light brown and fragrant.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly.
Add 1/4 cup of ghee to the pan and mix everything well until the mixture is crumbly.
Add 1 tablespoon of honey or sugar to the pan and mix everything well until the mixture is well combined.
Let the mixture cool completely before storing it in an airtight container.

name: Pantua
ingredients: Chhena, sugar, ghee, flour
instructions:
Heat 1 tablespoon of ghee in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 cup of chhena to the pan and sauté until it turns light brown and releases its moisture.
Add 1/2 cup of sugar to the pan and mix well until the sugar is fully dissolved.
Continue cooking the mixture for 5-7 minutes, stirring constantly, until it thickens and turns a deep brown color.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the mixture cool slightly.
Add 1 tablespoon of flour to the mixture and mix well until it forms a smooth dough.
Knead the dough for 2-3 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Divide the dough into small portions and shape each portion into a round ball.
Flatten each ball slightly into a disk shape.
Heat 1-2 tablespoons of ghee in a pan over medium heat and fry the Pantua until they are golden brown on both sides.
Remove the Pantua from the oil and place them on a paper towel to drain excess oil.
Serve the Pantua warm or at room temperature.

name: Papad
ingredients: Urad dal, sev, lemon juice, chopped tomatoes
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of urad dal and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the soaked urad dal and grind it into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of salt to the urad dal paste and mix well.
Cover the mixture and let it ferment in a warm place for 12-15 hours or overnight.
Once the mixture has fermented, add 1 tablespoon of sev and mix well.
Gradually add water to the mixture to form a thick batter, similar to pancake batter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat.
Using a ladle, pour a small amount of the batter onto the pan and spread it evenly to form a thin circle.
Cook the papad for 30-45 seconds or until the edges start to curl and the surface is dry.
Loosen the papad with a spatula and flip it over.
Cook the other side of the papad for another 30-45 seconds or until it is crispy and golden brown.
Brush the cooked papad with a few drops of lemon juice.
Sprinkle chopped tomatoes over the papad and serve hot.

name: Papadum
ingredients: Lentils, black pepper, vegetable oil
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of lentils and soak them in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the lentils and grind them into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of black pepper to the lentil paste and mix well.
Heat 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil in a non-stick pan over medium heat.
Using a spoon, drop small amounts of the lentil paste into the hot oil, about the size of a small marble.
Flatten each lentil paste ball slightly into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Cook the papadum for 30-45 seconds on the first side, until the edges start to curl and the surface is dry.
Flip the papadum over and cook for another 30-45 seconds, until crispy and golden brown.
Remove the papadum from the oil and place it on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Repeat the process with the remaining lentil paste, until all the papadum are cooked.

name: Paratha
ingredients: Wheat flour, butter, potato, coriander
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of wheat flour and a pinch of salt, then gradually add lukewarm water to form a soft dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable, then cover it with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Boil 1 large potato until it's tender, then peel and mash it in a bowl.
Add 1 tablespoon of chopped fresh coriander to the mashed potato and mix well.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 6-7 inches in diameter.
Place 1 tablespoon of the potato mixture in the center of each circle, then fold the dough over the filling to form a triangle or square shape.
Press the edges together to seal the paratha, making sure there are no gaps or openings.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat, then place a paratha on it and cook for 1-2 minutes, until it starts to puff up and the edges start to curl.
Brush the paratha with melted butter and flip it over, then cook for another 1-2 minutes, until it's golden brown and crispy.
Repeat the cooking process with the remaining parathas, serving them hot with your favorite accompaniments.

name: Paravannam
ingredients: Raw rice,  jaggery, milk
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of raw rice and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the soaked rice into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
In a large pan, combine 1 cup of milk and 1/2 cup of grated jaggery and heat it over medium heat, stirring occasionally.
Once the jaggery dissolves, add the ground rice paste to the pan and stir well to combine.
Cook the mixture over low heat, stirring constantly, until it thickens and reaches a porridge-like consistency.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the Paravannam cool to room temperature.
Serve the Paravannam warm or at room temperature, garnished with a sprinkle of cardamom powder if desired.

name: Paruppu sadam
ingredients: Arhar dal, sambar powder, tomato, curry leaves, fennel seeds
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of Arhar dal and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Drain the water and add 2 cups of fresh water to the dal in a pressure cooker.
Add 1 teaspoon of fennel seeds to the cooker and close the lid.
Pressure cook the dal for 3-4 whistles or until it is soft and mushy.
Let the pressure release naturally, then open the cooker and mash the dal slightly.
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat and add 5-6 curry leaves.
Saute the curry leaves until they are fragrant, then add 1 diced tomato.
Cook the tomato until it is soft and mushy, about 3-4 minutes.
Add 1 teaspoon of sambar powder to the pan and saute for 1 minute.
Add the mashed dal to the pan and stir well to combine with the tomato mixture.
Add salt to taste and 1 cup of water to the pan, then stir well.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 5-7 minutes or until the desired consistency is reached.
Serve the Paruppu sadam hot with rice or roti.

name: Patra
ingredients: Arbi ke patte, sesame seeds, gur, bengal gram flour, imli
instructions:
Wash the Arbi ke patte thoroughly and remove any stems or thick veins.
Dry the Arbi ke patte completely with a cloth or paper towels to remove excess moisture.
In a bowl, mix together 1 tablespoon of sesame seeds, 1 tablespoon of gur, and 1 tablespoon of Bengal gram flour.
Apply the sesame seed mixture evenly onto both sides of the Arbi ke patte, making sure to cover the entire surface.
Roll each Arbi ke patte tightly into a cylindrical shape, applying gentle pressure to form a compact roll.
In a large bowl, mix 1 cup of water with 1 tablespoon of imli paste to create a thin paste.
Dip each rolled Arbi ke patte into the imli paste, coating it evenly on all sides.
Place the coated Arbi ke patte rolls on a plate or tray, leaving some space between each roll to allow for even drying.
Let the Patra rolls dry completely in the air for at least 2-3 hours or until the imli paste is dry and set.
Once dry, the Patra is ready to be served or stored in an airtight container for up to 2 days.

name: Pattor
ingredients: Arbi ke patte, sesame seeds, gur, bengal gram flour, imli
instructions:
Wash and dry the Arbi ke patte, removing any excess moisture with a cloth.
In a bowl, mix together 1/2 cup of bengal gram flour, 1/4 teaspoon of sesame seeds, and a pinch of salt.
Add 1/4 cup of gur to the bowl and mix until the mixture is well combined and crumbly.
Dip each Arbi ke patte into the mixture, coating both sides evenly, and place them on a plate or tray.
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add 1 tablespoon of oil.
Place 2-3 coated Arbi ke patte in the pan and cook for 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Repeat step 6 with the remaining Arbi ke patte, adding more oil as needed.
In a small bowl, mix 1 tablespoon of imli with 1 tablespoon of water to make a paste.
Once the Arbi ke patte are cooked, brush the imli paste on top of each one.
Serve the Pattor hot with a sprinkle of sesame seeds on top.

name: Pav Bhaji
ingredients: Pav bhaji masala, gobi, potatoes, green peas, dinner rolls
instructions:
Boil the potatoes and gobi in water until they are tender, then drain the water and mash them together in a bowl.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat and add the mashed potato and gobi mixture, stirring well to combine.
Add green peas to the pan and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until they are tender.
Add pav bhaji masala to the pan and stir well to combine, cooking for 1-2 minutes until the masala is fragrant.
Add a splash of water to the pan and stir well to combine, then bring the mixture to a simmer.
Reduce the heat to low and let the mixture cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it has thickened slightly.
Split the dinner rolls in half and toast them lightly until they are warm and soft.
Serve the pav bhaji mixture hot, spooned onto the toasted dinner rolls.

name: Payasam
ingredients: Rice, cashew nuts, milk, raisins, sugar
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of rice and soak it in water for 30 minutes, then drain the water and set the rice aside.
Heat 1 tablespoon of ghee in a pan over medium heat and roast 1/4 cup of cashew nuts until they are lightly browned, then remove them from the pan and set them aside.
In the same pan, add 2 cups of milk and bring it to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer.
Add the soaked and drained rice to the simmering milk and cook, stirring occasionally, until the rice is fully cooked and the mixture has thickened.
Add 1/2 cup of sugar to the rice and milk mixture and stir until the sugar is fully dissolved.
Add the roasted cashew nuts and 1/4 cup of raisins to the mixture and stir well.
Continue to cook the mixture for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it reaches the desired consistency.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the payasam cool to room temperature before serving.

name: Payokh
ingredients: Basmati rice, rose water, sugar, clarified butter, cardamom pods
instructions:
Rinse the Basmati rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes, then drain the water and set the rice aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of clarified butter in a large saucepan over medium heat.
Add 2-3 crushed cardamom pods to the saucepan and let them sizzle for a few seconds until fragrant.
Add 1 cup of sugar to the saucepan and stir until it dissolves completely.
Add 1 cup of rose water to the saucepan and stir well to combine with the sugar mixture.
Add 2 cups of water to the saucepan and bring the mixture to a boil.
Drain the soaked Basmati rice and add it to the saucepan, stirring gently to combine with the sugar and rose water mixture.
Reduce the heat to low, cover the saucepan with a tight-fitting lid, and cook for 15-20 minutes or until the rice is cooked and fluffy.
Turn off the heat and let the Payokh rest for 5 minutes before serving.

name: Pesarattu
ingredients: Green moong beans, rice flour
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of green moong beans and soak them in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the soaked moong beans into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
In a large bowl, mix 1/2 cup of rice flour with the ground moong bean paste.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of salt to the bowl and mix well.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of water to the bowl and mix until a thick batter forms.
The batter should be thick enough to coat the back of a spoon, but still flow easily off it.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat.
Using a ladle, pour a small amount of the batter onto the pan and spread it evenly to form a circular shape.
Cook the pesarattu for 1-2 minutes, until the edges start to curl and the surface is dry.
Loosen the pesarattu with a spatula and flip it over.
Cook for another minute, until the other side is light brown and crispy.
Serve the pesarattu hot with your favorite chutney or upma.

name: Petha
ingredients: Firm white pumpkin, sugar, kitchen lime, alum powder
instructions:
Peel and cut the firm white pumpkin into small cubes, removing any seeds or stringy pulp.
Soak the pumpkin cubes in water for at least 2 hours to remove excess starch.
Drain the water and wash the pumpkin cubes thoroughly with fresh water.
Boil the pumpkin cubes in a large pot of water until they are tender, then drain the water.
Mix 1 cup of sugar with 1 cup of water to create a sugar syrup and bring it to a boil.
Add the boiled pumpkin cubes to the sugar syrup and cook for 10-15 minutes or until the syrup thickens.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of kitchen lime to the mixture and stir well.
Add 1/4 teaspoon of alum powder to the mixture and stir well.
Continue cooking the mixture for another 5-7 minutes or until the petha reaches the desired consistency.
Remove the pot from the heat and let the petha cool completely before serving.

name: Phirni
ingredients: Rice, sugar, nuts
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of rice thoroughly and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and blend the soaked rice into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
In a large pan, combine 2 cups of milk and 1 cup of sugar, and heat it over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the sugar dissolves.
Add the rice paste to the pan and cook, stirring continuously, for about 10-12 minutes or until the mixture thickens and comes away from the sides of the pan.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly.
Stir in 1/4 cup of chopped nuts, such as almonds or pistachios, into the phirni mixture.
Pour the phirni mixture into individual serving cups or a large serving dish.
Refrigerate the phirni for at least 2 hours or until chilled.
Serve the phirni chilled, garnished with additional chopped nuts if desired.

name: Pinaca
ingredients: Brown rice, fennel seeds, grated coconut, black pepper, ginger powder
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of brown rice in a fine mesh strainer until the water runs clear, then drain and set aside.
Heat a large saucepan over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of fennel seeds, letting them sizzle for 10-15 seconds.
Add 1 tablespoon of grated coconut to the saucepan and stir constantly for 1-2 minutes until lightly toasted.
Add 2 cups of water to the saucepan and bring to a boil.
Add the rinsed brown rice to the saucepan, stirring gently to combine with the coconut and fennel seeds.
Reduce the heat to low, cover the saucepan with a tight-fitting lid, and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the water is absorbed and the rice is cooked.
Once the rice is cooked, fluff it gently with a fork to separate the grains.
Stir in 1/4 teaspoon of black pepper and 1/4 teaspoon of ginger powder until well combined.
Serve the Pinaca hot, garnished with additional grated coconut if desired.

name: Pindi chana
ingredients: Fennel, tea bags, tomato, kasuri methi, cinnamon
instructions:
Heat oil in a pressure cooker over medium heat and add fennel seeds, letting them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add cinnamon sticks and sauté for another few seconds until fragrant.
Add chopped tomatoes and sauté until they start to break down and release their juices.
Add 2 cups of water to the cooker and bring to a boil.
Add 2 tea bags to the water and let it steep for 2-3 minutes, then remove the tea bags.
Add 1 cup of chickpeas (pindi chana) to the cooker and close the lid.
Pressure cook for 5-6 whistles or until the chickpeas are tender.
Open the cooker and add kasuri methi, stirring well to combine.
Let the mixture simmer for 5-7 minutes or until the flavors have melded together and the sauce has thickened slightly.
Serve hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Pithe
ingredients: Rice flour, wheat flour
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of rice flour and 1 cup of wheat flour.
Gradually add in 1/2 cup of lukewarm water to the flour mixture and mix until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the pithe for 30-45 seconds on each side, until they are lightly browned and puffed up.
Serve the pithe hot with your favorite filling or accompaniment.

name: Poha
ingredients: Beaten rice flakes, potato, curry leaves, green chilies, lemon juice
instructions:
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add a few curry leaves to it, letting them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add diced potatoes to the pan and sauté until they are lightly browned and cooked through, stirring occasionally.
Add green chilies, chopped into small pieces, to the pan and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add 2-3 cups of beaten rice flakes to the pan and stir well to combine with the potato and curry leaf mixture.
Squeeze a tablespoon or two of fresh lemon juice over the poha mixture and stir well to combine.
Continue to cook the poha for another 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until the flakes are well coated with the potato and spice mixture and heated through.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the poha cool slightly before serving.

name: Pongal
ingredients: Rice, jaggery, cashews, ghee
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Drain the water and cook the rice in 2 cups of fresh water until it is mushy and overcooked.
While the rice is cooking, melt 1/2 cup of jaggery in 1/2 cup of water over low heat, stirring constantly, until it dissolves completely.
Once the rice is cooked, mash it well with a spoon or blender to break down any lumps.
Add the melted jaggery mixture to the mashed rice and mix well.
Heat 2 tablespoons of ghee in a pan over medium heat and add 10-12 cashews.
Fry the cashews until they are golden brown and fragrant, then add them to the rice mixture.
Mix everything well and cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until the pongal is hot and well combined.
Remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Poornalu
ingredients: Chana dal, jaggery
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of chana dal and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the soaked chana dal into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
Transfer the ground paste to a bowl and add 1/2 cup of grated jaggery to it.
Mix the paste and jaggery well until the jaggery is fully dissolved and the mixture is smooth.
Cover the bowl with a cloth and let the mixture ferment in a warm place for 6-8 hours or overnight.
Once the mixture has fermented, add a pinch of salt to it and mix well.
Heat a non-stick pan or a cast-iron skillet over medium heat and grease it with a few drops of oil.
Using a spoon, drop small portions of the fermented mixture into the pan, about the size of a small lemon.
Flatten each portion slightly into a round shape and cook for 2-3 minutes or until the bottom is golden brown.
Flip the Poornalu over and cook for another 1-2 minutes or until they are golden brown on both sides.
Remove the Poornalu from the pan and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve the Poornalu warm or at room temperature.

name: Pootharekulu
ingredients: Rice flour, powdered sugar, ghee
instructions:
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add 1 tablespoon of ghee to it.
Once the ghee is hot, add 1 cup of rice flour and roast it until it turns light golden brown, stirring continuously.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the rice flour mixture cool down slightly.
Add 1/2 cup of powdered sugar to the roasted rice flour mixture and mix well until it is evenly distributed.
Knead the mixture until it forms a smooth dough, adding a little more ghee if necessary.
Divide the dough into small portions and shape each portion into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook each circle for about 30 seconds on each side, until it is lightly browned and crispy.
Remove the pootharekulu from the pan and let it cool completely before storing it in an airtight container.

name: Poriyal
ingredients: Chana dal, urad dal, beans, coconut, mustard
instructions:
Rinse 1/2 cup of chana dal and 1/2 cup of urad dal together and soak them in water for at least 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the dals into a coarse paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them splutter for a few seconds.
Add 1 cup of chopped beans (such as French beans or green beans) and sauté until they are tender.
Add the ground dal paste to the pan and sauté for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add 1/4 cup of grated coconut and stir well to combine.
Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, stirring frequently, until the poriyal is dry and the flavors are well combined.
Season with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Pork Bharta
ingredients: Boiled pork, onions, chillies, ginger and garlic
instructions:
Heat a tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1-2 chopped onions and sauté until they turn light brown.
Add 1-2 chopped green chillies and sauté for another minute.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger and 2-3 cloves of minced garlic and sauté for 30 seconds.
Add the boiled and shredded pork to the pan and stir well to combine with the onion mixture.
Cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the pork is well coated with the onion mixture and heated through.
Season with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Prawn malai curry
ingredients: Coconut milk, prawns, garlic, turmeric, sugar
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 2-3 cloves of minced garlic and sauté until fragrant, about 1 minute.
Add 1 teaspoon of turmeric powder and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add 1 cup of prawns and sauté until they start to turn pink, about 2-3 minutes.
Pour in 1 cup of coconut milk and stir well to combine.
Add 1 tablespoon of sugar and stir until dissolved.
Reduce heat to low and let the curry simmer for 5-7 minutes or until the prawns are cooked through.
Season with salt to taste, then remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Puli sadam
ingredients: Urad dal, lemon, tamarind, cooked rice, curry leaves
instructions:
Soak 1 cup of urad dal in water for at least 4 hours or overnight and drain the water.
Grind the soaked urad dal into a smooth paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and add 5-6 curry leaves and sauté until they turn light brown.
Add the ground urad dal paste to the pan and sauté for 5-7 minutes, stirring constantly, until the paste turns light golden brown.
Add 1/2 cup of tamarind juice to the pan and stir well to combine with the urad dal paste.
Add 1/4 cup of freshly squeezed lemon juice to the pan and stir well to combine with the urad dal paste and tamarind juice.
Add 2 cups of cooked rice to the pan and stir well to combine with the urad dal paste, tamarind juice, and lemon juice.
Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until the rice is well coated with the urad dal paste and the flavors are well combined.
Remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Puri Bhaji
ingredients: Aloo, urad dal, mustard, ginger, curry leaves
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of urad dal and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight, then drain and grind it into a smooth paste.
Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds, letting them splutter for a few seconds.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger to the pan and sauté for 10 seconds until fragrant.
Add 2-3 curry leaves to the pan and sauté for another 10 seconds until they start to change color.
Add 2-3 medium-sized boiled and mashed Aloo (potatoes) to the pan and mix well with the spice mixture.
Add salt to taste to the pan and mix well with the Aloo mixture.
Using the urad dal paste, make small balls, about the size of a small lemon, and flatten them slightly into patties.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium-high heat and when hot, add a few of the patties to the pan (do not overcrowd).
Fry the patties until they are golden brown and puffed up, flipping them halfway through, about 3-4 minutes per side.
Remove the fried puris from the oil and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve the puris hot with the Aloo bhaji prepared earlier.

name: Puttu
ingredients: Brown rice flour, sugar, grated coconut
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of brown rice flour and 1/2 teaspoon of sugar, and mix well until the sugar is evenly distributed.
Gradually add in 1/2 cup of grated coconut to the flour mixture and mix until the coconut is evenly coated with the flour mixture.
Add in 1/2 cup of water to the mixture and mix until a smooth dough forms, adding more water as needed to achieve the right consistency.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes pliable and smooth.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions, about the size of a small lemon.
Shape each portion into a cylindrical shape, about 3-4 inches long and 1 inch in diameter.
Place the shaped puttu in a steamer lined with a clean cloth or cheesecloth, leaving some space between each puttu for even cooking.
Steam the puttu over boiling water for 10-12 minutes, or until they are cooked through and fluffy.
Serve the puttu hot with your favorite accompaniments, such as coconut milk, banana, or chutney.

name: Qubani ka meetha
ingredients: Apricots, sugar syrup
instructions:
Rinse the apricots and soak them in water for at least 8 hours or overnight, then drain and chop them into small pieces.
In a large pan, combine the chopped apricots and enough water to cover them, and bring to a boil over high heat.
Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer the apricots for 20-25 minutes, or until they are soft and mushy.
Mash the cooked apricots with a spoon or potato masher to create a smooth pulp.
Add the sugar syrup to the apricot pulp and mix well to combine.
Cook the mixture over medium heat, stirring frequently, until the mixture thickens and the syrup is fully absorbed, about 10-15 minutes.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the Qubani ka meetha cool to room temperature.
Refrigerate the Qubani ka meetha for at least 2 hours before serving.

name: Rabri
ingredients: Condensed milk, sugar, spices, nuts
instructions:
Combine 1 can of condensed milk, 1/2 cup of sugar, and 1/4 teaspoon of cardamom powder in a heavy-bottomed saucepan and place it over medium heat.
Stir the mixture constantly until the sugar dissolves and the mixture comes to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and simmer the mixture for 10-12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it thickens slightly and turns a light golden brown.
Remove the saucepan from the heat and stir in 1/4 teaspoon of saffron threads, soaked in 1 tablespoon of hot water, and 1/4 teaspoon of rose water.
Let the mixture cool to room temperature, then cover and refrigerate it for at least 2 hours or overnight.
Just before serving, stir in 1/4 cup of chopped nuts, such as almonds or pistachios.
Pour the rabri into individual serving cups or a large serving dish and garnish with additional chopped nuts, if desired.
Serve the rabri chilled, garnished with a sprinkle of cardamom powder and a few strands of saffron, if desired.

name: Rajma chaval
ingredients: Red kidney beans, garam masala powder, ginger, tomato, mustard oil
instructions:
Rinse the red kidney beans and soak them in water for at least 8 hours or overnight, then drain and set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of mustard oil in a large pan over medium heat and sauté 1-inch piece of grated ginger until fragrant.
Add 1 large chopped tomato to the pan and cook until it's soft and mushy, stirring occasionally.
Add the soaked and drained red kidney beans to the pan and stir to combine with the tomato and ginger mixture.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder to the pan and stir well to combine with the beans and tomato mixture.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 20-25 minutes or until the beans are tender.
Serve the rajma hot over a bed of steaming hot rice, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Ras malai
ingredients: Chhena, reduced milk, pistachio
instructions:
Boil 1 liter of water in a large pot and add the chhena to it, then reduce the heat to medium and cook for 10-12 minutes or until the chhena is fully cooked and soft.
Drain the cooked chhena and let it cool to room temperature, then mash it gently with your hands or a spatula to remove any lumps.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the mashed chhena, 1/2 cup of reduced milk, and a pinch of salt, then mix well until smooth and creamy.
Divide the mixture into small portions, about the size of a small egg, and shape each portion into a smooth ball.
Flatten each ball slightly into a disk shape, making sure the edges are smooth and even.
In a large pan, combine 2 cups of reduced milk, 1/4 cup of sugar, and a few strands of saffron, then bring to a boil over high heat, stirring constantly.
Reduce the heat to low and simmer the milk mixture for 5-7 minutes or until it thickens slightly and coats the back of a spoon.
Add the shaped chhena disks to the simmering milk mixture and cook for 5-7 minutes or until they are fully coated and floating on the surface.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool to room temperature, then refrigerate for at least 2 hours or overnight.
Just before serving, garnish each ras malai with a sprinkle of chopped pistachio and a few strands of saffron, if desired.

name: Rasabali
ingredients: Chenna, sweetened milk
instructions:
Bring the sweetened milk to a boil in a deep pan over high heat, stirring occasionally.
Reduce the heat to medium and simmer the milk for 10-15 minutes, or until it thickens slightly and reduces to about half its original quantity.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly, until the milk is still warm but not hot.
Add the chenna to the warm milk and mix well until the chenna is fully incorporated and the mixture is smooth.
Pour the mixture into small, shallow molds or cups, filling them about 3/4 of the way full.
Refrigerate the molds for at least 2 hours, or until the rasabali is chilled and set.
Serve the rasabali chilled, garnished with a sprinkle of cardamom powder or a few chopped nuts, if desired.

name: Rasam
ingredients: Tomato, curry leaves, garlic, mustard seeds, hot water
instructions:
Crush 2-3 garlic cloves using a mortar and pestle or a garlic press to release their oils and flavor.
Heat 2 cups of hot water in a large saucepan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds to the hot water and let them sizzle for a few seconds until they start to pop.
Add 2-3 fresh curry leaves to the saucepan and let them simmer in the water for about 30 seconds.
Add 1 medium-sized diced tomato to the saucepan and let it cook for about 5 minutes or until it starts to break down and release its juices.
Mash the cooked tomato using a spoon or a potato masher to release its pulp and flavor into the water.
Continue to simmer the rasam for another 5-7 minutes or until the flavors have melded together and the liquid has slightly thickened.

name: Rasgulla
ingredients: Chhena, sugar, cardamom
instructions:
Boil 1 liter of water in a large pot and add 1 cup of sugar to it, stirring until the sugar is completely dissolved.
Bring the sugar syrup to a boil, then reduce the heat to medium-low and let it simmer for 5 minutes.
In a separate pan, knead the chhena until it becomes smooth and pliable, adding a few drops of water if necessary.
Divide the kneaded chhena into small balls, about the size of a small lemon, and flatten them slightly into oval shapes.
When the sugar syrup has simmered for 5 minutes, gently add the chhena balls to the syrup, being careful not to overcrowd the pot.
Cook the rasgullas in the sugar syrup for 10-12 minutes, or until they float to the surface, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.
Remove the rasgullas from the syrup with a slotted spoon and transfer them to a plate or tray.
Sprinkle a few drops of cardamom essence over the rasgullas and let them cool to room temperature.
Serve the rasgullas chilled, garnished with a sprinkle of cardamom powder if desired.

name: Red Rice
ingredients: Red pepper, red onion, butter, watercress, olive oil
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a large saucepan over medium heat.
Add 1 diced red pepper and cook for 5 minutes, or until tender.
Add 1 diced red onion and cook for an additional 5 minutes, or until softened.
Add 2 tablespoons of butter to the saucepan and stir until melted.
Add 2 cups of uncooked red rice to the saucepan and stir to combine with the pepper and onion mixture.
Add 4 cups of water to the saucepan and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until the water is absorbed and the rice is tender.
Fluff the cooked rice with a fork and stir in 1/4 cup of chopped fresh watercress.
Season with salt to taste, then serve hot.

name: Rongi
ingredients: Garam masala powder, tomato, kasuri methi, cinnamon, mustard oil
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of mustard oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 cinnamon stick to the pan and let it sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 1 medium-sized chopped tomato to the pan and sauté until it's soft and mushy.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder to the pan and mix well with the tomato.
Add 1 teaspoon of kasuri methi to the pan and mix well with the tomato and garam masala powder.
Continue to sauté the mixture for another 2-3 minutes, stirring frequently, until the flavors are well combined.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the Rongi cool down to room temperature.
Serve the Rongi hot or cold, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Saath
ingredients: Urad dal, potatoes, wheat flour, sooji
instructions:
Wash and soak 1 cup of urad dal in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the urad dal into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
Boil 2-3 medium-sized potatoes until they are tender, then peel and mash them.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the urad dal paste, mashed potatoes, and 1/2 cup of wheat flour, mixing well until a dough forms.
Add 1/4 cup of sooji to the dough and mix until it is evenly distributed.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a round ball.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the saath for 1-2 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Serve the saath hot with your favorite chutney or sabzi.

name: Sabudana Khichadi
ingredients: Raw peanuts, sabudana, lemon, avocado oil, curry leaves, green chili
instructions:
Rinse the sabudana thoroughly and soak it in water for at least 4-5 hours or overnight, then drain the water and set it aside.
Heat 1 tablespoon of avocado oil in a pan over medium heat and add 1-2 curry leaves, letting them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 1-2 green chilies, chopped, to the pan and sauté for about 10 seconds until fragrant.
Add 1/2 cup of raw peanuts to the pan and roast them until they are lightly browned, stirring frequently.
Add the soaked and drained sabudana to the pan and stir well to combine with the peanuts and spices.
Cook the sabudana mixture for about 5-7 minutes, stirring frequently, until the sabudana is cooked through and the mixture is dry.
Squeeze the juice of 1 lemon over the sabudana mixture and stir well to combine.
Season with salt to taste, then turn off the heat and let the khichadi cool slightly before serving.

name: Sambar
ingredients: Pigeon peas, eggplant, drumsticks, sambar powder, tamarind
instructions:
Pressure cook 1 cup of pigeon peas with 2 cups of water until 3-4 whistles, then set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté 1 medium-sized eggplant, cut into 1-inch pieces, until they turn light brown.
Add 2 medium-sized drumsticks, cut into 1-inch pieces, to the pan and sauté for another 5 minutes, or until they start to soften.
Add 1 teaspoon of sambar powder to the pan and sauté for 1 minute, stirring constantly, until the powder is fragrant.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 10 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender.
Soak 1 small ball of tamarind in 1 cup of hot water for 10 minutes, then mash and strain the mixture to extract the tamarind juice.
Add the cooked pigeon peas, tamarind juice, and salt to taste to the pan, and simmer for another 5-7 minutes, or until the sambar thickens slightly.
Serve the sambar hot with rice or idlis.

name: Samosa
ingredients: Potatoes, green peas, garam masala, ginger, dough
instructions:
Boil the potatoes until they are tender, then drain the water and let them cool.
Heat some oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté the grated ginger until fragrant.
Add the green peas to the pan and cook until they are tender, then set aside.
Mash the cooled potatoes in a bowl and add the cooked green peas, garam masala, and salt to taste, mixing well.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small egg.
Roll out each ball of dough into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Place a tablespoon or two of the potato mixture in the center of each dough circle.
Fold the dough over the filling to form a triangle or cone shape, pressing the edges together to seal the samosa.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium-high heat and fry the samosas until they are golden brown, turning occasionally.
Remove the samosas from the oil and drain on paper towels, serving hot.

name: Sandesh
ingredients: Milk, sugar, saffron, cardamom
instructions:
Boil 1 liter of milk in a heavy-bottomed pan over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until it reduces to half its original volume.
Add 1 cup of sugar to the reduced milk and stir until it dissolves completely.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly, until the mixture reaches a temperature of around 80°C to 90°C.
Add a few strands of saffron to the mixture and stir well to combine.
Cover the pan with a lid and let it sit for 10 to 15 minutes, allowing the saffron to infuse its flavor and color into the mixture.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of crushed cardamom to the mixture and stir well to combine.
Pour the mixture into a greased plate or tray and let it cool to room temperature.
Once the mixture has cooled and set, use a spatula or spoon to shape it into small squares or diamonds.
Serve the Sandesh chilled, garnished with a sprinkle of cardamom powder if desired.

name: Sandige
ingredients: Thin rice flakes, black sesame seeds, curry leaves
instructions:
Heat a large pan over medium heat and add 1 tablespoon of oil to it.
Add 1/2 cup of black sesame seeds to the pan and roast them until they start to crackle and change color.
Add a few curry leaves to the pan and sauté them for a few seconds until they are fragrant.
Add 2 cups of thin rice flakes to the pan and stir well to combine with the sesame seeds and curry leaves.
Roast the rice flakes mixture for about 5 minutes, stirring frequently, until the flakes are lightly toasted and fragrant.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the mixture cool completely.
Once the mixture is cool, store it in an airtight container to preserve the flavors and aroma.

name: Sattu ki roti
ingredients: Sattu, atta, dough, filling, mustard oil
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of atta and 1 cup of sattu, mixing well until the sattu is evenly distributed.
Gradually add water to the bowl and knead the mixture into a soft dough, covering it with a damp cloth for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions, rolling each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 6-7 inches in diameter.
Place 1-2 tablespoons of the prepared filling in the center of each circle.
Fold the dough over the filling to form a triangle or square shape, pressing the edges together to seal the roti.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat, brushing it with a small amount of mustard oil.
Place a roti on the pan and cook for 1-2 minutes, until it starts to puff up and the edges start to curl.
Flip the roti and cook for another 1-2 minutes, until it's golden brown and crispy.
Serve the sattu ki roti hot with a dollop of ghee or a side of vegetables.

name: Sev khamani
ingredients: Khaman, pomegranate, sev, powdered sugar, garlic
instructions:
Crush the garlic into a fine paste using a mortar and pestle or a garlic press.
Mix the crushed garlic with 1-2 teaspoons of powdered sugar in a small bowl until well combined.
Cut the khaman into small cubes and place them in a large mixing bowl.
Add the garlic-sugar mixture to the khaman cubes and toss gently until the khaman is evenly coated.
Sprinkle a handful of sev over the khaman mixture and toss again until the sev is evenly distributed.
Cut the pomegranate into small arils and sprinkle them over the khaman mixture.
Toss the mixture gently one last time to combine all the ingredients.
Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve the sev khamani chilled, garnished with additional sev and pomegranate arils if desired.

name: Sev tameta
ingredients: Sev, ginger, tomato, sugar
instructions:
Heat a small amount of oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add grated ginger to the pan and sauté until it turns light brown.
Add diced tomatoes to the pan and sauté until they are soft and mushy.
Add a small amount of sugar to the pan and stir well.
Add sev to the pan and stir well to combine with the tomato mixture.
Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until the sev is well coated with the tomato mixture.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly before serving.

name: Sevai
ingredients: Sevai, parboiled rice, steamer
instructions:
Rinse the parboiled rice thoroughly and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the soaked rice into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
Transfer the rice paste to a bowl and knead it well until it becomes a smooth dough.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions and shape each portion into a long, thin rope-like structure.
Place the Sevai maker or a steamer with a Sevai attachment on the stove over medium heat.
Place a portion of the dough rope into the Sevai maker or steamer and press it through the holes to form long, thin noodles.
Collect the Sevai noodles in a colander or strainer and repeat the process with the remaining dough portions.
Steam the Sevai noodles in the steamer for 10-15 minutes or until they are cooked through and fluffy.
Remove the Sevai from the steamer and let it cool completely before serving.

name: Shahi paneer
ingredients: Cottage cheese, malai, garam masala, ginger, tomato
instructions:
Cut the cottage cheese into small cubes and soak them in lukewarm water for 10-15 minutes to make them soft and tender.
Drain the water and squeeze out the excess water from the cottage cheese cubes.
Heat 2 tablespoons of malai in a pan over medium heat until it starts to melt and turn light brown.
Add 1-inch piece of grated ginger to the pan and sauté for 1 minute until fragrant.
Add 1 medium-sized chopped tomato to the pan and sauté for 2-3 minutes until it turns soft and mushy.
Add 1 teaspoon of garam masala powder to the pan and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add the cottage cheese cubes to the pan and stir gently to combine with the tomato-ginger mixture.
Cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the cottage cheese is fully coated with the masala and the mixture thickens slightly.
Season with salt to taste, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 2-3 minutes.
Serve the Shahi paneer hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro or mint leaves if desired.

name: Shahi tukra
ingredients: Rose water, milk, white bread slices, saffron, almonds
instructions:
Slice the white bread into 1-inch thick pieces and toast them until lightly browned.
In a large saucepan, combine 2 cups of milk, 1/4 teaspoon of saffron threads, and 1 tablespoon of rose water, and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let the milk simmer for 10-15 minutes, or until it thickens slightly and the flavors are well combined.
Remove the saucepan from the heat and let the milk mixture cool to room temperature.
Dip each toasted bread slice into the cooled milk mixture, coating both sides evenly.
Place the coated bread slices on a serving plate or tray.
Sprinkle sliced almonds over the bread slices.
Drizzle the remaining milk mixture over the bread slices, making sure they are well coated.
Refrigerate the Shahi tukra for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld together.
Serve the Shahi tukra chilled, garnished with additional sliced almonds if desired.

name: Shankarpali
ingredients: Sugar, ghee, maida flour, semolina
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of maida flour and 1/2 cup of semolina and mix well.
Add 1/4 cup of ghee to the flour mixture and mix until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of sugar to the mixture and mix until it forms a smooth dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat enough ghee in a deep frying pan over medium heat to deep-fry the circles.
When the ghee is hot, add a few circles to the pan (do not overcrowd) and fry until they are golden brown.
Remove the fried circles from the oil and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Repeat the frying process with the remaining dough circles.
Let the fried circles cool completely before storing them in an airtight container.

name: Sheer korma
ingredients: Vermicelli pudding, milk
instructions:
Begin by heating 1 cup of milk in a saucepan over medium heat until it starts to simmer.
Add 1/2 cup of vermicelli pudding to the milk and stir gently to combine.
Reduce the heat to low and cook for 5-7 minutes, or until the vermicelli is fully cooked and the mixture has thickened.
Remove the saucepan from the heat and let it cool slightly.
Stir the sheer korma gently to redistribute the vermicelli and create a smooth consistency.
Serve the sheer korma warm or chilled, garnished with a sprinkle of cardamom powder or chopped nuts if desired.

name: Sheera
ingredients: Semolina, ghee, nuts, milk
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of ghee in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1 cup of semolina to the pan and roast it until it turns light golden brown, stirring constantly.
Add 1 cup of chopped nuts to the pan and roast for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add 2 cups of milk to the pan and stir well to combine with the semolina and nuts.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring frequently, until the mixture thickens and the semolina is fully cooked.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly.
Add 1 tablespoon of ghee to the pan and mix well to combine.
Serve the sheera warm or at room temperature.

name: Shrikhand
ingredients: Curd, sugar, saffron, cardamom
instructions:
Hang the curd in a muslin cloth or a cheesecloth over a bowl for 2-3 hours to drain out the excess water.
Once the curd has thickened, transfer it to a mixing bowl and add the sugar.
Mix the curd and sugar until the sugar is fully dissolved and the mixture is smooth.
Soak a few strands of saffron in 1 tablespoon of hot water and let it infuse for a few minutes.
Add the saffron-infused water to the curd mixture and mix well.
Add the cardamom powder to the mixture and mix until well combined.
Refrigerate the mixture for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld together.
Serve the Shrikhand chilled, garnished with a few strands of saffron and a sprinkle of cardamom powder if desired.

name: Shufta
ingredients: Cottage cheese, dry dates, dried rose petals, pistachio, badam
instructions:
Soak the dried rose petals in 1 cup of warm water for 10-15 minutes or until they soften and release their color and fragrance.
Drain the rose petals and blend them with 1/2 cup of water to make a smooth paste.
Crumble the cottage cheese into a mixing bowl and add the rose petal paste, mixing well until the cheese is evenly coated.
Chop the dried dates into small pieces and add them to the cottage cheese mixture, mixing until they are evenly distributed.
Chop the pistachio and badam into small pieces and add them to the cottage cheese mixture, mixing until they are evenly distributed.
Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate the mixture for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
After 30 minutes, remove the bowl from the refrigerator and give the mixture a good stir.
Serve the Shufta chilled, garnished with additional dried rose petals and chopped nuts if desired.

name: Shukto
ingredients: Green beans, bitter gourd, ridge gourd, banana, brinjal
instructions:
Cut the bitter gourd, ridge gourd, and brinjal into 1-inch cubes and soak them in salt water for 30 minutes to remove bitterness.
Drain the soaked vegetables and wash them thoroughly under running water to remove excess salt.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté the bitter gourd, ridge gourd, and brinjal until they are lightly browned.
Add 1 teaspoon of turmeric powder and 1 teaspoon of salt to the pan and mix well.
Cut the green beans into 1-inch pieces and add them to the pan, stirring well to combine with the other vegetables.
Peel the banana and cut it into 1-inch pieces, then add them to the pan, stirring gently to combine.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring the mixture to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and simmer the mixture, covered, for 20-25 minutes or until the vegetables are tender.
Serve the Shukto hot, garnished with a sprinkle of mustard seeds and a dollop of ghee, if desired.

name: Singori
ingredients: Khoa, coconut, molu leaf
instructions:
Boil water in a large pan and add a few fresh molu leaves to it, letting them simmer for 5-7 minutes or until they become soft and pliable.
Remove the molu leaves from the water, let them cool, and then cut them into smaller pieces, discarding the stems.
In a separate pan, heat 1-2 tablespoons of ghee over medium heat and add the cut molu leaves, sautéing them until they are crispy and fragrant.
In a large mixing bowl, crumble 1-2 cups of khoa into small pieces, depending on the desired consistency of the singori.
Add the sautéed molu leaves to the crumbled khoa and mix well, breaking down any lumps with your fingers or a spoon.
Grate 1/2 cup of fresh coconut and add it to the khoa mixture, mixing until everything is well combined.
Shape the mixture into small, round balls, applying gentle pressure to bind them together.
Serve the singori at room temperature or refrigerate them for later use.

name: Sohan halwa
ingredients: Corn flour, ghee, dry fruits
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of ghee in a deep-bottomed pan over medium heat.
Add 1 tablespoon of corn flour to the pan and roast until it turns light golden brown, stirring constantly.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and stir well to avoid lumps.
Cook the mixture for 10-12 minutes or until it thickens, stirring frequently.
Add 1 tablespoon of ghee to the pan and stir well to combine.
Add 1/2 cup of chopped dry fruits (such as almonds, pistachios, and cashews) to the pan and stir well to combine.
Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes or until the halwa is smooth and shiny.
Remove the pan from the heat and let the Sohan halwa cool slightly before serving.

name: Sohan papdi
ingredients: Gram flour, ghee, sugar, milk, cardamom
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of gram flour and 1/2 cup of ghee, mixing until the gram flour is well coated with ghee.
Add 1 cup of sugar to the bowl and mix until the sugar is evenly distributed throughout the gram flour mixture.
Gradually add 1/2 cup of milk to the bowl, mixing until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add 1 tablespoon of ghee to it.
Place a few balls of dough in the pan and flatten them slightly into thin circles.
Cook the papdi for 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Remove the papdi from the pan and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess ghee.
Repeat the process with the remaining dough balls.
Once all the papdi are cooked, crush 1-2 cardamom pods in a mortar and pestle to release their seeds and powder.
Sprinkle the cardamom powder over the warm papdi and serve.

name: Sukhdi
ingredients: Whole wheat flour, gur, clarified butter
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of whole wheat flour and 1/2 cup of crushed gur.
Mix the flour and gur mixture well until the gur is evenly distributed throughout the flour.
Add 1/4 cup of clarified butter to the flour mixture and mix until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Gradually add a small amount of lukewarm water to the mixture and mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a round ball.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the sukhdi for 30-45 seconds on each side, until it is golden brown.
Repeat the cooking process with the remaining dough portions.
Serve the sukhdi warm or at room temperature.

name: Surnoli
ingredients: Rice flakes, yogurt, raw rice, jaggery, grated coconut
instructions:
Soak 1 cup of raw rice in water for at least 4 hours or overnight, then drain the water and grind it into a fine paste.
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of rice flakes, 1/2 cup of grated coconut, and 1/4 cup of jaggery powder.
Add the ground raw rice paste to the mixing bowl and mix well until everything is fully incorporated.
Gradually add 1 cup of yogurt to the mixture and mix until a thick dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small portions, shape each portion into a round ball, and flatten it slightly into a disk shape.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the Surnoli disks for 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Repeat the cooking process with the remaining dough portions.
Serve the Surnoli warm or at room temperature with your favorite chutney or accompaniment.

name: Sutar feni
ingredients: Maida, sugar, ghee
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of maida and 1 cup of sugar and mix well until the sugar is evenly distributed.
Add 1/4 cup of ghee to the maida-sugar mixture and mix until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Gradually add more ghee to the mixture, 1 tablespoon at a time, until the mixture comes together to form a smooth dough.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the sutar feni for 30 seconds on each side, until they are lightly browned and puffed up.
Remove the sutar feni from the pan and let them cool completely on a wire rack.
Store the sutar feni in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.

name: Tandoori Chicken
ingredients: Greek yogurt, garam masala, kasuri methi, marinade, mustard oil
instructions:
In a large bowl, whisk together 1/2 cup Greek yogurt, 2 teaspoons garam masala, 1 teaspoon kasuri methi, and 1 tablespoon marinade until smooth.
Add 1 1/2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken thighs to the marinade and mix until the chicken is well coated.
Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or overnight.
Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C).
Remove the chicken from the marinade, letting any excess liquid drip off.
Place the chicken on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper and brush with 2 tablespoons mustard oil.
Bake the chicken for 20-25 minutes, or until it is cooked through and slightly charred.
Serve the Tandoori Chicken hot, garnished with fresh cilantro if desired.

name: Tandoori Fish Tikka
ingredients: Chickpea flour, biryani masala powder, yogurt, fish fillets, green bell pepper
instructions:
In a large bowl, mix together 1/2 cup chickpea flour, 1 teaspoon biryani masala powder, and 1/2 teaspoon salt.
Add 1/2 cup yogurt to the bowl and mix until the chickpea flour is well combined and the mixture is smooth.
Cut 4 fish fillets into 1-inch cubes and add them to the bowl, making sure they are well coated with the marinade.
Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes or up to 2 hours.
Preheat a grill or grill pan to medium-high heat.
Remove the fish cubes from the marinade, letting any excess liquid drip off.
Thread the fish cubes onto skewers, leaving a little space between each piece.
Brush the grill or grill pan with oil to prevent sticking.
Grill the fish skewers for 4-5 minutes per side, or until they are cooked through and slightly charred.
While the fish is grilling, slice 1 green bell pepper into large pieces and brush with oil.
Grill the bell pepper pieces for 2-3 minutes per side, or until they are slightly charred.
Serve the grilled fish skewers with the grilled bell pepper pieces and enjoy!

name: Thalipeeth
ingredients: Whole wheat flour, rice flour, pearl millet flour, sorghum flour, sesame seeds
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup whole wheat flour, 1/2 cup rice flour, 1/4 cup pearl millet flour, and 1/4 cup sorghum flour.
Add 1/2 teaspoon salt to the flour mixture and mix well.
Gradually add 1/2 cup lukewarm water to the flour mixture and mix until a soft dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions and shape each portion into a ball.
Roll out each ball into a thin circle of about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Sprinkle a few sesame seeds over the rolled-out dough, leaving a 1-inch border around the edges.
Fold the edges of the dough over the sesame seeds to form a square or triangle shape, and press the edges gently to seal.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the thalipeeth for 2-3 minutes on each side, until it is golden brown and crispy.
Serve the thalipeeth hot with your favorite accompaniment, such as chutney or raita.

name: Thayir sadam
ingredients: Urad dal, curd, sesame oil, ginger, curry leaves, mustard seeds
instructions:
Rinse 1 cup of urad dal and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the urad dal into a smooth paste using a grinder or blender.
Heat 1 teaspoon of sesame oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 small piece of grated ginger and sauté for a few seconds until fragrant.
Add 1 sprig of curry leaves and sauté for another few seconds until they start to curl.
Add 1/2 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them sizzle for a few seconds until they pop.
Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly.
In a large bowl, mix together the urad dal paste, 1 cup of curd, and the cooled pan mixture until well combined.
Season with salt to taste, if desired.
Mix well and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve the thayir sadam chilled.

name: Theeyal
ingredients: Coconut, whole red beans, masala, sesame oil, tamarind
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of sesame oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 1 teaspoon of masala and sauté for 10 seconds until fragrant.
Add 1 cup of whole red beans and sauté for 2-3 minutes until they start to change color.
Add 1 cup of grated coconut and sauté for 5 minutes until it turns light brown, stirring frequently.
Add 2 tablespoons of tamarind paste and sauté for another minute, stirring well.
Add 1 cup of water to the pan and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the beans are cooked and the sauce thickens.
Remove from heat and let it cool before serving.

name: Thepla
ingredients: Chickpea flour, methi leaves, jowar flour, wheat flour
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup chickpea flour, 1/2 cup jowar flour, and 1/2 cup wheat flour.
Add 1/4 teaspoon salt and mix well.
Add 1/4 cup chopped fresh methi leaves and mix until the leaves are evenly distributed.
Gradually add 1/2 cup lukewarm water and mix until a soft dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 6-8 equal portions.
Roll out each portion into a thin circle, about 6-7 inches in diameter.
Heat a non-stick skillet or griddle over medium heat.
Place a thepla on the skillet and cook for 30-45 seconds or until bubbles appear on the surface.
Flip the thepla and cook for another 30-45 seconds or until it is golden brown.
Repeat with the remaining dough portions.
Serve the theplas hot with your favorite accompaniments.

name: Til Pitha
ingredients: Glutinous rice, black sesame seeds, gur
instructions:
Rinse the glutinous rice thoroughly and soak it in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain the water and grind the soaked rice into a fine paste using a grinder or blender.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the ground rice paste, 1/2 cup of water, and a pinch of salt; mix well until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 10-15 minutes until it becomes pliable and smooth.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Flatten each ball into a thin circle, about 3-4 inches in diameter.
Place a small spoonful of gur in the center of each circle.
Sprinkle a few black sesame seeds over the gur.
Fold the dough over the filling to form a half-moon shape, and press the edges together to seal the pitha.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and cook the pithas for 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown.
Serve the Til Pitha warm or at room temperature.

name: Turiya Patra Vatana sabji
ingredients: Ridge gourd, baking soda, sugar, grated coconut, peas
instructions:
Peel and chop the ridge gourd into small pieces and soak them in water with 1 teaspoon of baking soda for 10-15 minutes.
Drain the water and wash the ridge gourd pieces thoroughly to remove any bitterness.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté the ridge gourd pieces until they are tender and lightly browned.
Add 1 teaspoon of sugar to the pan and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Add 1 cup of peas to the pan and sauté until they are tender and well combined with the ridge gourd.
Add 2 tablespoons of grated coconut to the pan and sauté for another minute, stirring constantly.
Season with salt to taste and mix well.
Serve the Turiya Patra Vatana sabji hot with roti or rice.

name: Undhiyu
ingredients: Sweet potato, surti papdi, baby potatoes, valor papdi, green peas
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds, letting them sizzle for a few seconds.
Add 1 small onion, finely chopped, and sauté until it turns light brown, about 5 minutes.
Add 2 cloves of minced garlic and sauté for another minute, until fragrant.
Add 1 large sweet potato, peeled and diced, and sauté for about 5 minutes, until it starts to soften.
Add 1 cup of surti papdi, cleaned and chopped, and sauté for 2-3 minutes, until it starts to soften.
Add 1 cup of baby potatoes, peeled and halved, and sauté for another 2-3 minutes, until they start to soften.
Add 1 cup of valor papdi, cleaned and chopped, and sauté for 2-3 minutes, until it starts to soften.
Add 1 cup of green peas and sauté for 2 minutes, until they start to soften.
Add 1 teaspoon of grated ginger, 1 teaspoon of turmeric powder, 1 teaspoon of red chili powder, and salt to taste, and sauté for 1 minute, until the spices are well combined.
Add 1 cup of water and bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for 15-20 minutes, or until all the vegetables are cooked through.
Serve the undhiyu hot, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro, if desired.

name: Unni Appam
ingredients: Rice flour, banana, jaggery, coconut
instructions:
In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of rice flour and 1/2 cup of grated coconut.
Mash 1 ripe banana and add it to the bowl, mixing well to combine.
Add 1/2 cup of powdered jaggery to the bowl and mix until a smooth dough forms.
Knead the dough for 5 minutes until it becomes soft and pliable.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls, about the size of a small lemon.
Heat a non-stick pan or appam chatti over medium heat.
Place a dough ball in the pan and flatten it slightly to form a round shape.
Cook the appam for 2-3 minutes on the first side, or until the edges start to curl.
Flip the appam and cook for another 1-2 minutes, until it is golden brown.
Repeat with the remaining dough balls.
Serve the unni appam warm or at room temperature.

name: Upma
ingredients: Chana dal, urad dal, ginger, curry leaves, sugar
instructions:
Rinse the Chana dal and urad dal together and soak them in water for at least 30 minutes.
Drain the water and grind the dal mixture into a coarse paste using a blender or grinder.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat and add the grated ginger; sauté until fragrant.
Add the curry leaves to the pan and sauté for another minute, until they start to change color.
Add 2 cups of water to the pan and bring to a boil.
Gradually add the ground dal paste to the boiling water, stirring continuously to prevent lumps from forming.
Reduce the heat to low and cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring frequently, until the mixture thickens and the dal is fully cooked.
Add 1 teaspoon of sugar to the pan and stir well to combine.
Cook for an additional 1-2 minutes, until the sugar is fully dissolved and the Upma is heated through.
Serve hot.

name: Uttapam
ingredients: Chana dal, urad dal, thick poha, tomato, butter
instructions:
Rinse and soak 1 cup of chana dal and 1/2 cup of urad dal in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
